Lorenzo Ghiberti's bronze doors on the Baptistry are empaneled with magnificent bas relief scenes of biblical history and legends. Ghiberti's work took decades to accomplish, was hailed as the early masterpiece of Renaissance art, and later furnished inspiration to Michaelangelo. (In 1956, when I saw the doors, they were still attached to the Baptistry, where for five hundred years they had been exposed to the possibility of vandalism, and the ravages of time and weather, but in 1990, at long last, they were removed for protection to a nearby museum, and replaced by modern replicas.)

Ghiberti's "Gates of Paradise" [Michaelangelo's term for them]:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/ricardobevilaqua/2601068466/]

Much later, in the United States, Ghiberti's doors furnished inspiration for the 19th-century "Columbus Doors" on the Capitol, in Washington -- doors which depict scenes of the quest for India and discovery of America, by Christopher Columbus, in 1492 (only a few decades after Ghiberti finished his doors). These doors, which lack the finesse and genius of Ghiberti's, were the work of Randolph Rogers, an American-born sculptor (chiefly of Civil War monuments), whose studio and workshop were located in Rome.

Located in the Valle delle Cartiere near Toscolano-Maderno (Lago di Garda) in Lombardia Italy, this was one of the if not the largest paper mill in that region. There was quite a large number of paper mills located in the valley. Some of them were active up to the 1950's and 1960's. Maina Inferiore belonged to the Maffizzoli family, which finally founded the only remaining paper mill in Toscolano-Maderno. This new mill is still producing. The mill shown on the picture today serves as a museum for the valley's history.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/24736216@N07/] I live in Naples from 1972 :) Posillipo hill extends over 5km from NE to SW. The photo was taken on the NE edge, where the Posillipo hill meets the Vomero.

Penso che il titolo corretto sia "Mangiatori di spaghetti". Primo perché si tratta di spaghetti, non di maccheroni (cosi detti maccaroni all'americana). Secondo non mi pare che abbiano un banco di vendita, piuttosto un bel piatto dove mangiare. Ed è quindi logico immaginare che questo ritratto sia una scherzosa parodia del ben più famoso quadro fiammingo "Mangiatori di patate". 
Se avete voglia traducete voi il mio commento in inglese. Grazie, Buona giornata.

This is what Bing translator came up with:
I think the correct title is "spaghetti eaters". First because it's spaghetti, not Macaroni (so called American maccaroni). 2nd I do not think that they have a sales counter, rather a dish to eat. And it is therefore logical to imagine that this picture is a playful parody of the much more famous painting Dutch "potato eaters".
If you fancy you translate my comment in English. Thanks, have a nice day.

The original caption of the photochrome is „NAPOLI . MACCHERONAIO“. It seems, that the maccheronaio was a popular topic on postcards from naples at that time, showing people producing, selling or eating pasta. The maccheroni look always like spaghetti or bucatini today, see the following examples:

Via ProQuest... PERSONS AND PLACES OF INTEREST The Hartford Courant (1887-1922) - Hartford, Conn. Date:Jan 25, 1914 JEANNETTE McILWAINE Jeannette McIlwaine has separated from her football hero husband Howard Sykes formerly of Yale and in dancing on the roof of the New ...

A short marriage: YALE MAN SECRETLY WEDS.; Howard C. Sykes Sends Word from Paris -- Will Not Return to College. The New York Times. January 29, 1913, Wednesday Page 1, 146 words A romantic Christmas marriage came to light tonight when Howard c. Sykes of the senior class of the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale send word from Paris that he and Miss Jeanette C. McIlwayne of Wheeling, West Va., were married in New York City during the holidays, and that he would not return to Yale. The couple met in a New Jersey town, and, after a brief courtship, were married and went abroad. The bride is a granddaughter of Gen. Crook, the Indian fighter, and a niece of Gen. Kelly. Sykes lives at 346 West Seventy-first Street, New York City. He was a leading scholarship member of his class, and belonged to the secret society York Hall.

Having escaped from a New York insane asylum in 1913 and fled to Canada, Harry K. Thaw, the murderer of Architect Stanford White, was extradicted back over the border to the U. S., then spent several months in limbo in Concord, New Hampshire, resisting return to New York for a trial on escape charges. He finally was hauled back to NY on January 23, 1914. In 1915 he was judged restored to sanity, and let off scott free.

Bain has dated the photo January 20, 1914, which was about two months before the birth of Sir Alec Guinness, the famous actor, on April 2nd of that year. Loel Guinness (1906-1988) biography -- the Wikipedia version: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loel_Guinness Tate Gallery's biography of Meraud Guinness Guevara (1904-1993): www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ArtistWorks?cgroupid=999999961&am...

The New York Times of December 28, 1913, has the story of the children's party given the day before by Mrs. Benjamin S. Guinness, of London and New York, at her New York residence, 8 Washington Square. Loel and Meraud played the roles of King and Queen in a children's comedy written for the occasion by Walter Creighton, "The Nosed Princess." (Young Alice Astor played the title role of Princess Cayenne Pepper.) The occasion was the birthday of another Guinness daughter, Tanis. Several Astors were present, and "motor cars were arriving with the children of society." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9407E2DF113FE6...

Alexis Carrel (1873-1944), French surgeon and eugenicist, won 1912 Nobel Prize in Physiology: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexis_Carrel His wife was the former Anne-Marie-Laure Gourlez de La Motte. They married in 1913; she was a widow, Mme. de la Meyrie, with one son at the time. In the summer of 1914, while she was pregnant, she was stung by a bee and miscarried as a result of her severe allergic reaction. She lived into the 1970s.

The New York Times story (December 19, 1913) about the scandalous doings at the Atlantic Cat Club's 12th annual championship show, held in the Belvedere of New York's Astor Hotel, fails to mention either Miss M. Johnson or her stunning white cat, Abdullah. Interestingly, a cat named Toto was mentioned -- a cat so extraordinary that it was to be transported to England, there to be entered in an international cat fanciers' exhibition at London's Crystal Palace. (Toto probably derived its name from that of Dorothy's little dog in the Oz books -- books which were all the rage then.) query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9A05E...

Another NYT story, from five days earlier, reported the suicide (in New Jersey) of a black cat, 13 years old, on December 13, in the year 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D07E3D61139E6... uncanny, huh?

The French Bull Dog club held a dog show there too, as this Bain photo attests:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5169004217/]

In December 1913, the New York TImes reported on the arrival of Carrie T. Van Gaasbeck, Alfred A. Berger, and J. T. Price, three tuberculosis survivors who hiked from Los Angeles to Washington DC to deliver a letter asking President Wilson for research on tuberculosis treatments and cures. The hiking, in winter, was part of the demonstration that they were, indeed, cured of TB. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9801E1D6103FE633A...

This appears to the be the Burgess Model I flying boat (not to be confused with the Burgess Model I Scout) built for Robert J. Collier. Famed aviator Frank Coffyn tested the aircraft for Collier at Marblehead, Massachusetts (dating the photo to July/August 1913). The engine is a 220 horsepower Anzani 20 radial engine, an immensely powerful engine for the era featuring two 10-cylinder rows. In fact, this particular engine (visible just behind Coffyn) may be the very first of its type built and sold by Italian motor manufacturer Anzani. www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200722...

The ball he is holding is a "medicine ball."  I am old enough to remember them...we even used them when I was in high school.  They were balls full of lead pellets, so they sometimes weighed close to 40 pounds.  Typically, two or more guys would pass the ball to each other to build up strength.  Somewhere there is a famous photo of Babe Ruth working out with one.

As far as I know, they are no longer manufactured.

Oh, they still make medicine balls! en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medicine_ball In a 1917 annual report, a Louis S. Reingold was listed as a parole agent for the Jewish Prisoner's Aid Branch of the Jewish Protectory and Aid Society, based on Second Avenue in New York City. books.google.com/books?id=GzQbAQAAIAAJ

I remember medicine balls in basketball practice in the 60's.  And we learned about Hoover ball in IA history.


Hooverball is a medicine ball game invented by President Herbert Hoover's personal physician to help keep then-President Hoover fit. The Hoover Presidential Library Association and the city of West Branch, Iowa, co-host a national championship each year.

In general, the game is played on a volleyball-type court of grass or sand and involves throwing a heavily weighted medicine ball over the net. Officially, in Hooverball, the medicine ball weighs about 6 lb (2.7 kg) and is thrown over an 8 ft (2.4 m) volleyball-type net.

The Gregory, a steamship of the Booth Line, came to the rescue of the Oklahoma, which was wrecked on Sandy Hook on January 4, 1914. www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4690771132/ is of the captain of the Bavaria, another ship that rescued some of the few survivors. See NYT of January 7, 1914. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F03E7DF1E39E633A...
His coat is an example of the oiled seal skin they used to wear.

Captain Graalfs (NYTimes spelling) of the "Bavaria" gave his firsthand account of the 1914 destruction of the "Oklahoma," an oiltanker owned by Gulf Refining Company of New York City.  Thirty-two men were lost in the wreck of the Oklahoma.
NYT article of Jan 6, 1914 is at query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9504E7DD1730E733A...
Men from the "Bavaria" went to rescue survivors of the wreck of the oilship Oklahoma in January 1914.

Another Bain/LOC photo of the Gunboat Smith vs. Arthur Pelkey fight in San Francisco [Daly City] on January 1, 1914: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4668752209/in/photostream/] "After thirty seconds figiting in the fifteenth round Smith feinted with his left, then swung his right with lightning-like rapidity. The blow landed with a crash on Pelkey's unprotected jaw. Pelkey dropped with his eyes glassy. Mechanically he struggled to his feet at the count of nine and unsteadily assumed his fighting pose. A left and right applied similarly toppled him and he was out when Referee Griffin awarded the fight to Smith." --From NYT report, 1/2/14. Story in New York Times, January 2, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9D02E...
Note to LOC: The correct spelling of the name is "Pelkey." The date of the fight was January 1, 1914 -- not January 8.

Wystan,

Thanks for the further information on this fight.  As you can see in the record, and on the negative, Bain recorded the date of Jan. 8, 1914, and we qualify those dates as possibly later than the event and sometimes the date of publication or acquisition by Bain.  We will also add the date of the event itself  (Jan. 1, 1914) to the record when we expand the descriptive details, and clarify the difference between those two dates.

The January 8, 1914 date inscribed on the Bain News Agency's negative is confusing, because the fight in San Francisco [Daly City] between Gunboat Smith and the Canadian newcomer, Arthur Pelkey, took place on January 1, as reported in the New York Times, in a story that appeared in the January 2 edition: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9D02E... Another Bain/LOC photo of the Gunboat Smith vs. Arthur Pelkey fight shows Pelkey knocked to the canvas in the fifteenth round, as the referee begins his count: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4669377234/in/photostream/] "After thirty seconds figiting in the fifteenth round Smith feinted with his left, then swung his right with lightning-like rapidity. The blow landed with a crash on Pelkey's unprotected jaw. Pelkey dropped with his eyes glassy. Mechanically he struggled to his feet at the count of nine and unsteadily assumed his fighting pose. A left and right applied similarly toppled him and he was out when Referee Griffin awarded the fight to Smith."
Note to LOC: Your caption on this photo is incorrect. Correct spelling of name is "Pelkey." Correct date is January 1, 1914.
Gunboat Smith en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunboat_Smith

Wystan, Thanks for the information on this fight. We will expand and correct the information regarding the date and other details. I saw your note on the photo itself: "There appears to be a message here, printed in capital letters over the water." That white area along the back is actually a fence enclosing the ampitheater, and the text is an advertisement for Kissel Kars, it turns out. Kissel Kars was opening a new salesroom and service station in San Francisco not long after this fight, so they were advertising in the area. The text on the fence is straight from their ad in the San Francisco Chronicle, though it is quite hard to make out: Kissel Pleasure Kars Kissel Kommercial Kars Federal Trucks Ford Cars
That link to the Kissel ad in the San Francisco Chronicle goes thru ProQuest, and evidently (unless we obtain a note from teacher) is unavailable to us of the hoi polloi.

Wystan, I was afraid of that! Unfortunately, since it is a subscription database (ProQuest Historical Newspapers), it's not possible for me to grant access. It is a resource subscribed to by many larger research facilities and universities, though. At any rate, there is little substance in the link beyond what I quoted. The ad was published in the San Francisco Chronicle on Jan. 11, 1914, and is titled: Announcement of our Formal Opening, then begins: The Pacific Kissel Kar Branch cordially invites the public to call and inspect its new spacious salesroom and service station (the Largest on the Pacific Coast) during the week of January 12th to 17th... The four types of vehicles are arrayed on the left and right side of this main block of text. Sorry for any confusion with that link.

Prince William's aunt Queen Elisabeth of Romania, on learning that the Great Powers were looking for a prince to rule over Albania, asked Take Ionescu to attempt to persuade them to appoint her nephew to the post. Eventually the European Great Powers -- Austria-Hungary, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, the French Third Republic, the German Empire, the Russian Empire and the Kingdom of Italy -- selected William, a member of the German princely house of Wied, to rule over newly-independent Albania. The announcement was made in November 1913 and the decision was accepted by Ismail Qemali, the head of the provisional government. The offer of the Albanian throne was first made to him in the spring of 1913 but he turned it down. Despite rejecting the offer, the Austrians put pressure on Prince William in an attempt to change his mind en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_of_Wied en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_of_Albania Prince Weid sounds better than King Zog

quigley_brown: Good question! This photograph is part of the George Grantham Bain Collection, which consists of the photographic files of the Bain News Service. (A brief collection description can be found here.) The Bain News Service sometimes collected photographs from other sources and made copy glass negatives of those images. The Library of Congress scanned the glass negatives produced by the Bain News Service and that is what you are seeing here.

Built for millionaire New York clothier Isaac Brokaw. Brokaw's eldest son, George, who inherited the mansion, was briefly married to Clare Boothe, but she divorced him. What you can't see in the photo on the left, directly across 5th Ave from the mansion, is Central Park. The mansion became the offices of the IEEE in the 1940s, and they have published a nice history of the building, along with photos of the exterior and interior, on their website at www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Brokaw_Mansion:_IRE_Headqu....

Gifford Pinchot (PIN-sho) pioneering conservationist, was the first chief of the U. S. Forest Service, and the 28th Govenor of Pennsylvania. He first checked into the Battle Creek Sanitarium in January, 1911. Prohibitionist and Vegetarian Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, a Seventh-Day Adventist, was the eccentric dictator of the Battle Creek Sanitarium. (His brother, Will K. Kellogg, started the Kellogg's cereal company -- beginning with corn flakes -- as an offshoot of the Sanitarium's work in developing health foods. C. W. Post, a patient at the "San," also liked the bland diet there, and became the multi-millionaire owner of the Post Cereals Company.) Samuel Sidney McClure (1857-1949) was the founder of the McClure Newspaper Syndicate and editor-publisher of McClure's Magazine, a muckraking organ of the Progressive movement, from 1893 to 1911. Through his magazine, McClure boosted recognition and acceptance of the early-childhood educational theories of Maria Montessori. "He is a firm believer in the value of the low-protein diet, which he claims has doubled his ability for work and quadrupled his endurance. . . ." Iriving Fisher (1867-1947) was an American economist, health reformer, and eugenicist. When he contracted TB, he "took the cure" at the Battle Creek Sanitarium, and afterwards became a health reformer himself. He introduced the practice of calorie counting as part of a diet regimen. He was also a Prohibitionist: Prohibition of alcohol was a major tenet of the Seventh Day Adventists and of Dr. Kellogg's Sanitarium. Sir H. Plunkett, Irish Unionist, had been for twenty years the Minister for Agriculture for Ireland. In Ireland, he promoted the ideals of the Battle Creek Sanitarium: books.google.com/books?id=5KnhAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA16&dq... This photo appears to have been taken in the sunny conservatory (Palm Garden) of the Battle Creek Sanitarium. The building's exterior, in another Bain/LOC photo: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4647156705/] Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, impresario of the "San": [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4647770910/in/photostream/]

Pinchot's papers are at the Library of Congress. Included is a daily diary, so it is probably possible to determine the date and place this photo was taken. Pinchot mentions Plunkett and McClure in his autobiography, Breaking New Ground.

A photograph depicting the same men (possibly a print from this plate) is held amongst Horace Fletcher's papers in the Houghton Library of Harvard University. It's with some clippings from 1911 - suggesting it was taken that year. See item no. 63 at this finding guide: oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~hou00218 That may also be an avenue for inquiry. Alas I've never been to Boston and may never go there.
"The Battle Creek Idea" for January 6, 1911, mentions that Pinchot, McClure, Plunkett, and Fisher are all there: books.google.com/books?id=cKfhAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA8&dq=...

It's too bad that Horace Fletcher isn't in this photo -- he was an even odder food faddist than this bunch. Fletcher's book, "Fletcherism," defined proper mastication of food as chewing every bite thirty-two times before swallowing -- once for each tooth. The process became known as "Fletcherizing," and the word "Fletcherize" entered the dictionaries (at least briefly).

"Pinchot . . . long suffered from problems of the eye, skin and digestive system. In January 1911 he enrolled in the John Harvey Kellogg Sanitarium in Battle Creek, Michigan. The notion of preventive medicine -- staying well rather than getting cured -- was innovative, and the high-mindedness of Kellogg's program, which centered on obedience to natural law as a moral duty, obviously appealed to Pinchot. Kellogg's ban on alcohol and tobacco would not have been a problem, but Pinchot had a sweet tooth and probably thought twice about the restriction on chocolate."
--intro to The Conservation Diaries of Gifford Pinchot, edited by Harold K. Steen

As noted above, this photo probably dates from 1911. The likely occasion for Bain circulating it to his subscribers in 1913 was a banquet of repeat visitors to the Battle Creek Sanitarium, held at the "San" on October 28, 1913. LOC -- Your title misspells his last name. "Gooch," not "Groogh."

And yet, this fellow with the big V on his football uniform (in a portrait taken in Charlottesville, Va.) would seem to be Robert K. Gooch, a football quarterback hero who led the University of Virginia team to shutout seasons in 1914 and 1915. Much later, as a PoliSci professor, he advocated for the abolition of football scholarships, according to this source: books.google.com/books?id=sT7EMa71OD4C&pg=PA119&l... A biographical sketch: "The Robert Kent Gooch Professorship in Government and Foreign Affairs was funded by friends of the chair’s namesake. A Rhodes Scholar, Robert Gooch (College ’14, Graduate Arts & Sciences ’15) joined the faculty in 1924. He retired four decades later, having been chair of the Department of Government and Foreign Affairs, director of the Institute of Public Affairs, head of the Honors Program, University marshal, and dean of the College of Arts & Sciences. An authority on comparative government and European parliamentary government, Mr. Gooch advised President Franklin Roosevelt during World War II. He died in 1982." im.dev.virginia.edu/endowments/professorships/long_name/c... A November, 1914 account of the Virginia/North Carolina Game, in which Gooch played: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20612F83C5C1373...

John Harvey Kellogg (1852-1943), doctor, inventor of corn flakes. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Harvey_Kellogg

Prohibitionist and Vegetarian, Dr. John Harvey Kellogg was the man who built the Battle Creek Sanitarium, and presided there for decades. His brother, Will Keith Kellogg, started the breakfast food company, Kellogg's of Battle Creek..

Wikipedia\
 "John Kellogg and his brother Will Keith Kellogg started the Sanitas Food Company to produce their whole grain cereals around 1897, a time when the standard breakfast for the wealthy was eggs and meat, while the poor ate porridge, farina, gruel, and other boiled grains. John and Will later argued over the recipe for the cereals (Will wanted to add sugar to the flakes). So in 1906, Will started his own company, the Battle Creek Toasted Corn Flake Company, which eventually became the Kellogg Company, triggering a decades-long feud. John then formed the Battle Creek Food Company to develop and market soy  products.

The Kelloggs did not invent the concept of the dry breakfast cereal. That honor belongs to Dr. James Caleb Jackson, who created the first dry breakfast cereal in 1863, which he called, "Granula." A patient of John's, Charles William Post, would eventually start his own dry cereal company, Post Cereals, selling a rival brand of corn flakes. Dr. Kellogg later would claim that Charles Post stole the formula for corn flakes from his safe in the Sanitarium office.

Gerald Carson (1899-1989) told the whole convoluted story of the Kellogg brothers, their rise to fame, and their prickly relationship in his book, "Cornflake Crusade" (1957). Carson, a former advertising man, wrote well, and wrote funny. The book is hilarious. 

Like this photo, Gerald Carson's papers are in the Library of Congress.

The dark appearance of many of these old glass negatives is due to deterioration of the emulsion, not any defect in photographic technique. There are plates from the Civil War collection whose positives look almost completely black.

These LOC reference images are machine-generated, digitally "inverted" (positive) versions of the original glass plate negatives. You generally have to adjust them yourself to get something that looks good. Example of this one in particular: www.shorpy.com/node/12398?size=_original

LOC -- Bain's original caption is incorrect. Close scrutiny of the sign shows that the fundraising drive is for both the YMCA -- AND the YWCA. There is an M perched directly above the W on the sign. It should properly be rendered YM/YWCA, or YMCA/YWCA.

The fundraising "clock" sign was positioned on a prominent corner, but this was the Wall Street construction site for the new headquarters of J. P. Morgan -- not the site of the future YM/YWCA. The address on the sign, 25 Broad Street, was the location of the existing YMCA headquarters, not of the J. P. Morgan erection. New York's four-million-dollar whirlwind campaign for a new YM/YWCA was the largest fundraising project in world history up to that time. Campaign "clocks" like the one shown here were erected at various strategic locations to keep the project in the public eye. This story in the "New York Times," November 13, 1913, mentions another one: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9501E...

Bain's photographer overdid his coverage of this spectacle, but that probably was all for the best, since half of his shots were grievously underexposed:

"The James Speyer House was a mansion located at 1058 Fifth Avenue, on the southeast corner of 87th Street, in the Upper East Side of New York City. It was constructed for James Speyer, a New York City banker. It was a reticent classicizing block of three storeys and a set-back attic storey over a sunk basement lit by a light well; it had five bays on the avenue, where the upper two floors were linked by a colossal order of pilasters, and seven bays on the side street." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Speyer_House

Best name ever, yes. Wikipedia knows more:
Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve (October 23, 1831 – January 9, 1924), American classical scholar, was born in Charleston, South Carolina, son of Emma Louisa Lanneau and Benjamin Gildersleeve (1791–1875), a Presbyterian evangelist, and editor of the Charleston Christian Observer from 1826 to 1845, of the Richmond (VA) Watchman and Observer from 1845 to 1856, and of The Central Presbyterian from 1856 to 1860. He married 18 Sep 1866 in Middlebury, Loudon, Virginia, Eliza Fisher Colston. B.L. Gildersleeve graduated from Princeton in 1849 at the age of eighteen, and went on to study under Johannes Franz in Berlin, under Friedrich Ritschl at Bonn and under Schneidewin at Göttingen, where he received his doctor's degree in 1853. From 1856 to 1876 he was professor of Greek at the University of Virginia, holding the chair of Latin also from 1861 to 1866. After service for the Confederate States Army in the American Civil War, during which Gildersleeve was shot in the leg, he returned to the University of Virginia.[1] Ten years later, he accepted an offer from Daniel Coit Gilman of a position at The Johns Hopkins University. In 1880, the American Journal of Philology, a quarterly published by the Johns Hopkins University, was established under his editorial charge, and his strong personality was expressed in the department of the Journal headed "Brief Report" or "Lanx Satura," and in the earliest years of its publication every tiny detail was in his hands. His style in it, as elsewhere, is in striking contrast to that of the typical classical scholar, and accords with his conviction that the true aim of scholarship is "that which is." He published a Latin Grammar (1867; revised with the co-operation of Gonzalez B. Lodge, 1895 and 1899; reprinted 1997 with a bibliography of twentieth-century work on the subject) and a Latin Series for use in secondary schools (1875), both marked by lucidity of order and mastery of grammatical theory and methods. His edition of Persius (1875) is of great value. But his bent was rather toward Greek than Latin. His special interest in Christian Greek was partly the cause of his editing the Apologies of Justin Martyr (1877), "which" (to use his own words) "I used unblushingly as a repository for my syntactical formulae." Gildersleeve's studies under Franz had no doubt quickened his interest in Greek syntax, and his logic, untrammeled by previous categories, and his marvelous sympathy with the language were displayed in this most unlikely of places. His Syntax of Classic Greek (Part I, 1900, with CWE Miller) collects these formulae. Gildersleeve edited in 1885 The Olympian and Pythian Odes of Pindar, with a brilliant and valuable introduction. His views on the function of grammar were summarized in a paper on The Spiritual Rights of Minute Research delivered at Bryn Mawr on June 16, 1895. His collected contributions to literary periodicals appeared in 1890 under the title Essays and Studies Educational and Literary. He was elected president of the American Philological Association in 1877 and again in 1908 and became a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters as well as of various learned societies. He received the degree of LL.D. from William and Mary (1869), Harvard (1896), Yale (1901), Chicago (1901), and Pennsylvania (1911); D.C.L. from the University of the South (1884); L.H.D. from Yale (1891) and Princeton (1899); Litt.D. from Oxford and Cambridge (1905). Gildersleeve retired from teaching in 1915. Gildersleeve House, one of the undergraduate dormitories at Johns Hopkins, is named in his honor.
via en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basil_Lanneau_Gildersleeve

Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve, philologist, in his day was acknowledged as the doyen of Classical scholars in the U. S. He was remembered as a great wit. Eugenicist, warden of a women's prison, and first director of New York City's Bureau of Social Hygiene: "The Bureau of Social Hygiene grew out of the appointment of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. to a special grand jury investigation of the white slave trade in New York in 1910. Rockefeller served as foreman for this investigation, which was scheduled to last for one month. He kept the investigation going for six months and in the end released a detailed report calling for a permanent commission to investigate "social evil… in the leading cities of this country and Europe…."(1) When the mayor refused to set up such a commission, JDR Jr. decided to do it himself. (2) He interviewed over a hundred educators, intellectuals and businessmen about the project. On March 22, 1911, the Committee of Three (JDR Jr., Paul Warburg and Starr Murphy) met and organized the Bureau of Social Hygiene. The name was first used in October 1911, although the organization was not formally incorporated until 1913.(3) KATHERINE B. DAVIS, former commissioner of Charities and Correction of New York and superintendent of the Bedford Hills Reformatory for Women, was chosen as the first general secretary.(4) The purpose of the Bureau was 'the study, amelioration, and prevention of those social conditions, crimes, and diseases which adversely affect the well being of society….'" The full article expands on the pseudoscience and slipshod analytical methods of Eugenics devotees: www.ferris.edu/HTMLS/othersrv/isar/archives2/sources/bsh.htm

Admiral Winslow was described as "every inch a sailor," and "the handsomest flag officer in the Navy." He was a friend of former President Theodore Roosevelt, who had been Secretary of the Navy in his early career. In September, 1913, speculation in a New York Times story focused on Winslow as the likely future leader of the Atlantic Fleet, who would lead the fleet to the Pacific Ocean by way of the Panama Canal upon its completion in 1915. It's the Salvation Army Duo

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4586273427/in/photostream/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4586272645/in/photostream/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4586897370/in/photostream/] 1500 officers of the Salvation Army in America, assembled in New York City for a convention, were visited by General Bramwell Booth from England, the S.A.'s international head. Bramwell had become the second general of the Salvation Army after the death of his father, General William Booth, in 1912. While in New York, Bramwell Booth also visited his sister Eva, head of the United States' branch of the Army, and his brother, General Ballington Booth, the head of the Volunteers of America, an organization that had broken away from the Salvation Army, 17 years earlier. Bramwell Booth (1856-1929) was the second General of the Salvation Army, succeeding his father, William Booth, founder of the organization. Bramwell's sister, Evangeline (Eva) Booth (1865-1950), became the Army's fourth General (1934-39). A naturalized U. S. citizen, Eva was the Army's Commander of the United States from 1904 to 1934. These photos, dated November 26, 1913 (the day before Thanksgiving), show the parade of Salvation Army faithful who accompanied Bramwell to the docks that morning to see him off for England aboard the "France," a ship of the French Line. New York Times story, November 25, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=2&res=9C03E...

Another Bain/LOC photo of Roosevelt in Rio de Janeiro: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4627034718/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4818011373/] A Bain/LOC photo of Mrs. Roosevelt in Rio: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4627033802/] Former President Theodore Roosevelt, at age 55, defeated in his 1912 attempt at election for a third term as the candidate of the Progressive ("Bull Moose") Party, in 1913 sailed for Brazil to embark on his life's last great adventure, exploring the uncharted rain forest via the River of Doubt. Marked by poor planning, inadequate equipment, and a surfeit of bad luck, the expedition was harrowing, to put it mildly, and TR nearly died (as in fact some in the party did) -- but ultimately in 1914 he and his son, Kermit, and others in the party made it back to the embrace of civilization. (And the River of Doubt now bears the name Rio Roosevelt.) Roosevelt lived to write a book about his ordeal, "Through the Brazilian Wilderness." The story has recently been updated and retold in a gripping bestseller (2005) by Candice Millard -- "The River of Doubt; Theodore Roosevelt's Darkest Journey," a book that comes highly recommended by its many readers, myself included. Wikipedia entry on the River of Doubt: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roosevelt_River

A giant at 6'6, 240 pounds, Jess Willard faced charges of second-degree murder stemming from the death of his youthful opponent, John "Bull" Young, from a blow to the head in the ninth round of a boxing match on August 22, 1913. Willard's powerful right uppercut had driven Young's jaw up into his brain. On January 13, 1914, a jury found Willard not guilty. In 1915, after defeating Jack Johnson in Havana, Willard became heavyweight champion of the world -- but after that he avoided fights as champ, because Buffalo Bill was paying him a minimum of a thousand dollars a day to appear as an attraction in the fabled Wild West Show -- easy money that Willard would have lost, had he lost the title. (He finally did lose -- in 1919, to Jack Dempsey, in Toledo, Ohio.)

Budderflyman: 
At least three concerns hold us back from editing images. 

Authenticity: Digitizing a photograph as it has survived through time reassures viewers that we're representing the original artifact faithfully. Editing an image undermines the reliability of the photo as a historical document. Once we start covering up even small scratches, who's to know how much other image content we changed.
 
Subjective choices: Different users have different preferences when it comes to replacing scratches, pumping up contrast, sharpening edges, cropping negative borders, etc.  Offering the basic image lets subsequent users make their own decisions about which features to change to suit a particular purpose or product.

Lack of money and time: If we had lots more resources, offering a 'cleaned up photo' in addition to the 'raw document' could be considered.  (Like pre-conservation and post-conservation images of a damaged and then repaired poster.) But our priority is basic digital access -- many more of the Library’s 14 million pictures should be available online first.

Well, this photo has one blatant black blotch which if removed would not bother anyone, I am sure.

I am not asking you to edit sharpness, crops, borders, etc.  It is just cleaning up a piece of debris that I am sure no photographer would ever wish to have on his or her photo.  With a clone tool, this takes one second to correct.  

But, I will not bug you again about it.

Well if you want to head down that road then you might as well remove the clear sticky tape marks on the bottom and bottom left, not the mention the hundred other scratches. For the reasons the LOC have outlined, they're dead right to leave them as they have them.

A perfunctory Google search turns up few clues as to the identity of "Mrs. A. Pederneiras." Nor is she mentioned in the cursory New York Times stories that reported stages of Theodore Roosevelt's South American excursion. Mrs. Roosevelt (Edith Carow Roosevelt) went with TR to Argentina, Brazil and Chile, but did not accompany the former President on his expedition to the interior of the continent, through the insect-infested rain forest and down the River of Doubt. Mrs. Roosevelt left Chile in late November, 1913, to begin her return journey to the U. S.

Ivan Mamutoff, the cossack, wrestled at Madison Square Garden on March 10, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9D0DEFDC133EE7...

But Mamutoff was in the news already in November, 1913, a few weeks before the Bain News Agency circulated this photo to its subscribers.

Story in the "New York Evening Telegram," November 13, 1913:

RUSSIAN GIANT WRESTLER HERE; HOPES TO MEET GOTCH

Ivan Mamutoff of St. Petersburg, a Russian soldier of the Tsar's bodyguard and an expert wrestler, arrived here today on board the steamship Ryndam, having secured a special leave of absence of six months for a tour of the United States and Canada, during which he is desirous of meeting the world's champion wrestler, Frank Gotch. Manutoff is thirty-one years old, six feet four inches in height, and weighs 245 pounds. Four years ago he threw Geoge Hackenschmidt and Johan Kock in Graeco-Roman matches.

(In the photo above, Mamutoff is posed before a weirdly-painted backdrop that appears to be leaning against a wall -- perhaps in a photographer's studio?)

Mrs. Blanche A. W. Heye was involved in a newsy Long Island divorce case in summer 1913. Her ex-husband was George G. Heye, a banker in Manhattan. Frank Munsey, author and publisher: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Munsey

Munsey was a founder of the Progressive Party, and an enthusiastic backer of former President Teddy Roosevelt in his bid for a third term in the election of 1912. Because he thus split the GOP-oriented vote with the incumbent, William Howard Taft, Roosevelt swung the election to the Democratic challenger, Woodrow Wilson.
President and briefly owner of the Red Sox.

Joseph John Lannin, a native of Canada, came up from poverty to own several hotels in the U. S. He acquired the Boston Red Sox in 1914, for $200,000 (a princely sum at the time) and owned the team for only three years. He is remembered for hiring Babe Ruth, but a later team owner let Ruth go. In 1928, Lannin died under peculiar circumstances, falling from a high window of his Brooklyn (N.Y.) hotel.

The fire was Dec. 3, 1913, in Boston; 28 people were killed.

Another BAIN/LOC photo of the Wright Flying Boat:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4606575008/]

After Glenn Curtiss invented the first flying boat in 1912, capturing a valuable chunk of business from the U. S. Navy, Orville Wright decided that his Wright Aircraft Company should develop a competing version. He hired a young engineer, Grover Loening, to design the new aeroboat, which was tested successfully in the fall of 1913.

The photograph shows a test of the craft on Ohio's Miami River, near Dayton, in November, 1913.

Essentially the Wright brothers' 1903 airplane, but attached to an innovative, metal alloy boat hull. The Wrights should have spent less time in court suing Glenn Curtiss.

Incredible photo, LOC! Many thanks!

Leroy Grumman worked for Loening and went on to base his first floatplanes on Loening's later design. Grumman Aircraft was thus established and is merged now with Northrup. So from the Wright's first flight, to the Grumman built manned lunar lander, this aircraft is directly connected to the most significant achievements of human flight!

In 1913, on his second visit to America (the first was in 1893), his Imperial Highness visited Philadelphia, Newport RI, and New York City. In New York, the Grand Duke stayed at the Ritz-Carlton hotel. One of several photos that Bain took there is dated September 6, 1913. After his departure for Russia, the New York Times (on October 5, 1913) ran a story about the unpretentious royal visitor, and included a story about a famous joke that Alex had played on the press in 1893: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9406EEDF1E3BE633A...

During his visit to Newport, Rhode Island in 1913, His Imperial Highness, The Grand Duke Alexander Mikhailovich of Russia (1866-1933), was struck by the beauty of American women. According to published reports, The Grand Duke "collected photographs of the women he met in Newport, especially at The Casino and Bailey's Beach." The Grand Duke was particularity smitten by Miss Marie Tailer of New York City, who was visiting Newport at that time, and he was "anxious to obtain a photograph of her". He declared that Miss Tailer was "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World". [1] This pronouncement was picked up by newspapers across the country (if not the world), and photos of Miss Tailer were published for some years afterwards -- always with the "Most Beautiful Girl in the World" moniker in the caption. [2] Marie Tailer was engaged in 1914, and married in 1915, to Mr. S. Bryce Wing. A photo of her is included in the LOC Bain Collection on Flickr -- however IMNHO there are more flattering photos of her in The (San Francisco) Call and The (Georgia) Evening Ledger.                         "Miss Marie Tailer (right) 1913"   from Bain / LOC

Brander Matthews (1852-1929), professor of dramatic literature at Columbia University: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brander_Matthews

In the year 1913, when the Bain News Service circulated this photo to its subscribers, Brander Matthews published a book, "Shakespeare as a Playright," and was elected president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

From the Columbia Encyclopedia:
"Brander Matthews (James Brander Matthews), 1852-1929, American author and teacher, b. New Orleans. Matthews was a well-known figure in theatrical and literary circles in Paris and London as well as in New York City. He began to teach at Columbia Univ. in 1891 and in 1900 was appointed the first professor of dramatic literature in any American university. A founding member of several writers' clubs, he had considerable influence on the playwrights of the period from 1890 to 1915. His works include The Development of the Drama (1903), Principles of Playmaking (1919), and Playwrights on Playmaking (1923). His gift of model stage sets, costumes, and books is now the Brander Matthews Dramatic Museum at Columbia." 

Bibliography: See his autobiography, These Many Years (1917).

LOC, I think Bain made an error with this photo. I have checked the (admittedly meagre) "track and field" online photo file on the University of Michigan's Bentley Historical Library website, and find no pix of anyone wearing shirts with this peculiar design, of three C's with an arrow through them. All true Michigan shirts have the famous block "M" logo on the front, and track at Michgan was called "track," not cross country. Michigan is my alma mater, and I have lived in Ann Arbor for all of my 67 years. I have seen many U-Mich photos during those years, but never one like this, with three C's on the shirts. Maybe Bain's clerk wrote Mich. by mistake, intending to write "Minn.," for Minnesota?

While we're on the subject: Bain's caption reads "Univ. Mich.," NOT "Mich. U.," as the LOC title wantonly has it. "Mich. U." is just plain WRONG, and leads to confusion with Michigan State University, the agricultural school in East Lansing (confusion which is all-too-frequent as it is).

USS Chester Chester was the first U.S. Warship built with reaction-type steam turbines, making her one of the fastest ships of her time. fascinating class, www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/ship/cl-1.htm also pictured here www.historycentral.com/navy/cruiser/Chester.html The first Chester (CL-1) was launched 26 June 1907 by Bath Iron Works, Bath, Maine, sponsored by Miss D. W. Sproul; and commissioned 26 April 1908, Commander H. B. Wilson in command. In the period prior to World War I, Chester operations included training activities off the east coast and in the Caribbean, participation in the Fleet Reviews of February 1909, October 1912, and May 1915, and many duties of a diplomatic nature. She carried a Congressional committee on a tour of North Africa in 1909, and the next year joined in a special South American cruise commemorating the 300th anniversary of the founding of Buenos Aires, Argentina. As American interests in the Caribbean were threatened by internal political troubles in several nations Chester patroled off Mexico, Santa Domingo, and Haiti, and transported Marine occupation force in 1911. Later that year she carried men and stores to Scorpion, station ship at the then Austrian port of Trieste, returning to Boston with the American consul at Tripoli. After a period in reserve from 15 December 1911 to 5 November 1913, Chester returned to duty in the Gulf of Mexico guarding American citizens and property during the revolution in Mexico. She joined in the occupation of the customs house at Vera Cruz 21 April, and transported refugees to Cuba, performed various diplomatic missions, and carried mail and stores to the squadron off Vera Cruz until 19 June 1914. She returned to Boston for overhaul and another period in reserve, from 12 December 1914 to 4 April 1915.

This is Miss Marjorie Brown (1892-1988) of Atlanta. Marjorie was a daughter of First Lady Ellen Wilson's cousin, Colonel Edward T. Brown of Atlanta. She had two brothers, Edward M. and Henry W. Brown. [1] [2]   Growing up in Georgia, Marjorie was a long-time childhood friend of Jessie and Eleanor Wilson, and she later shared her college years with Jessie in Princeton. Marjorie attended Miss Jessie Wilson as one of five bridesmaids at her White House wedding to Francis B. Sayre in November, 1913, and she was also a special guest at the wedding of Eleanor Wilson, six months later at the White House. [3] [4]   A portrait of Marjorie Brown appeared in The Atlanta Constitution on November 9, 1913. (shown below) Marjorie married Benjamin M. King in Washington, DC, in December, 1920. Miss Margaret Wilson, daughter of the president, was maid of honor, and former First Lady Edith Wilson was among the guests. [5] Benjamin King had been engaged to Eleanor Wilson. He was the manager of a lumber camp near Madera, Mexico when Eleanor met him while traveling with friends in 1913. The President and Mrs. Wilson liked King and approved of the engagement. However, Eleanor broke the engagement when she met William McAdoo later in 1913. Wilson and King remained friends, and after Benjamin and Marjorie married they would visit the Wilson’s. [6]   "Miss Marjorie Brown" by Meade

I just did a quick calculation. There are 40,000 Bain negatives according to the Library of Congress. If they are releasing them at a rate of 40 per week it will take 1,000 weeks to complete the project. With 52 weeks in the year it will take 19.2 years to complete the project. We can round that up to 20 years since most weeks there are less than 40, and for several weeks none were posted. 

The LOC also has a newspaper scanning project that is equally slow paced.  

For a comparison, Google Books started in 2004 and scanned 10 millions books by the end of 2009. That is 2 million books a year, or 40K books a week, if they take of two weeks for vacation, which I am sure they do not.

Anyone else have thoughts on the pace of the project?

Richard, another problem is that LOC keeps interleaving other batches of photos in here, interrupting the Bain flow. I could survive nicely without the gaudy tourist shots of Ireland, the Farm Administration pix (already famous elsewhere) and the front pages of tabloid newspapers. Last Friday, we were given 48 Bain photos to puzzle out, but we could easily have handled a hundred. If LOC insists on dumping the other stuff onto Flickr, I suggest that they run three or four separate photostreams, so that they can keep the several feeds coming at a steady pace, while those of us who wish to do so can focus on the historically-fascinating Bain archive, and ignore the others.

This photograph of Vita at twenty-one may have been taken in 1913 for publicity purposes, when her engagement to Harold Nicolson was announced. They were wed on October 1, 1913, which surely was why Bain distributed copies of the photo to his clients at that time. At the time of her marriage, she was deeply, passionately in love -- with a young woman. As members of Britain's landed gentry, her family qualified as newsworthy. Harold Nicolson was a diplomat, posted to the British legation in Turkey, which was then the center of the Ottoman Empire.

Its also a shame that Google Goggles has been disabled for face searching to preserve privacy on the Internet. Google Googles is the latest iteration of Google's image matching software. I am sure it would match many of these images to already labeled photos of these people from Wikipedia.

As regular travelers in the Bain Collection in Flickr, it may interest you to know we processed the collection with caption information from two main sources: caption cards and the negatives themselves. (As noted in the Notes area in the record.) The records were primarily created from the caption cards, and sometimes later amended with information from the negatives (or negative sleeves). 

This is why you will often see differences between the information recorded in the title area and the information on the image itself.

Chicago physician Rosalie M. Ladova (check spelling), arrested in the July 1913 for refusing to swim in a skirted bathing costume.  "Dr. Ladova is an expert swimmer and is accustomed to wear a heavy two-piece bathing suit with full bloomers.  This morning, feeling hampered by the skirt, she laid it at the water's edge and swam out into the lake.  She was followed by one of the life guards, who told her to put on the skirt or submit to arrest....  'Men have absolutely no right to go around with their limbs bare and compel women to wear cumbersome suits,' she said.  'The system is wrong.  Men and women should bathe separately, and women should not be persecuted when they dress as comfortably as men do.'"

Apparently the judge dismissed the charge of disorderly conduct, ruling her outfit not indecent.

I happened to be in London with my parents in the autumn of 1956. We had the luck to be spectators at the Lord Mayor's parade. The LM at that time (Sir Cullum Welch) was dressed up just like this -- it's a big deal over there.

I was surprised to learn that, in addition to the Lord Mayor of London (now officially Lord Mayor of the City of London) there is also a Mayor of London. The Mayor of London doesn't get the title of Lord, but he governs a much larger chunk of territory called Greater London.

Frederick Augustus III (German: Friedrich August III.); (25 May 1865 in Dresden – 18 February 1932 in Sibyllenort) was the last King of Saxony (1904–1918) and a member of the House of Wettin. Born in Dresden, Frederick Augustus was the son of King George of Saxony (1832-1904) and his wife Maria Anna, Infanta of Portugal (1843-1884). He was an older brother of Princess Maria Josepha of Saxony. His maternal first cousins included (among others) Carlos I of Portugal, Infante Afonso, Duke of Porto, Prince Wilhelm of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen and Ferdinand I of Romania. Frederick Augustus served in the Royal Saxon Army before becoming king, and later was promoted to Generalfeldmarschall. He abdicated as king on 13 November 1918, after the defeat of the German Empire in World War I. He died in Sibyllenort (now Szczodre) in Lower Silesia and was buried in Dresden. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Augustus_III_of_Saxony

This is a man that all Hoosiers know.

The Hoosier Poet James Whitcomb Riley (1849-1916), -- wealthy, wildly popular, alcoholic -- had suffered a stroke in 1910, and in 1913 began using a cane as he learned to walk again. According to a caption in Riley's Wikipedia biography, this photograph was taken at a "Riley Day" celebration in Cincinnati, in November, 1913. Riley's train passed through Cincinnati every year, on the way from his summer home in Greenfield, Indiana, to winter quarters in Florida. Wikipedia on Riley: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Whitcomb_Riley

This appears to be an old photo of Fireman Jim Flynn that the Bain agency copied and circulated to its subscribers at the end of November, 1913, to publicize Flynn's two upcoming fights in New York City, against Battling Levinsky (December 9) and George Rodel (December 22).

A dozen other Bain/LOC photos of Jim Flynn have already been posted to Flickr.

He was not born a Flynn:
"Assuming an Irish name was not unusual in that era of boxing; there were Jewish fighters with Irish names too; and Jim Flynn, the only man who ever knocked out Jack Dempsey, was actually named Andrea Chiariglione. One reason for the name changes is that there were not enough Irish fighters to satisfy the large number of Irish fans." -- Pete Hamill, "Why Sinatra Matters" (Boston: Little, Brown, 1998), p. 58.

This was at The Cottage Baths at Neptune Beach, Alameda CA. It was established in 1917 so that makes this photo a touch latter then notated above. "Neptune Beach was an amusement park on the shore of San Francisco Bay in the city of Alameda, California. The park was served by the Southern Pacific Transportation Company and ferries from San Francisco. It operated from 1917 until it closed in 1939. Opened in 1917, Neptune Beach occupied a beach front zone now known as Crab Cove and was originally owned by the Strehlow family. Admission to the park was a dime. The park was described as a place for private picnics, with a clubhouse for dancing, and barbecue pits. The Cottage Baths were vacation cottages, available for rent. There were dances on Friday and Saturday night." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neptune_Beach_(California)

The bather wearing the ALAMEDA swimsuit is my Grandmother, Nell Schmidt, the first woman to swim across the bay from Alameda to San Francisco. She is now honored in the International Swimming Hall of Fame.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4627035426/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4586272645/in/photostream/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4586897370/in/photostream/] 1500 officers of the Salvation Army in America, assembled in New York City for a convention, were visited by General Bramwell Booth from England, the S.A.'s international head. Bramwell had become the second general of the Salvation Army after the death of his father, General William Booth, in 1912. While in New York, Bramwell Booth also visited his sister Eva, head of the United States' branch of the Army, and his brother, General Ballington Booth, the head of the Volunteers of America, an organization which had broken away from the Salvation Army, 17 years earlier. Bramwell Booth (1856-1929) was the second General of the Salvation Army, succeeding his father, William Booth, founder of the organization. Bramwell's sister, Evangeline (Eva) Booth (1865-1950), became the Army's fourth General (1934-39). A naturalized U. S. citizen, Eva was the Army's Commander of the United States from 1904 to 1934. These photos, dated November 26, 1913 (the day before Thanksgiving), show the parade of Salvation Army faithful who accompanied Bramwell to the docks that morning to see him off for England aboard the "France," a ship of the French Line. New York Times story, November 25, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9C03E...

On December 15, 1913, Diry, a middleweight, was knocked out by George Ashe in the third round of a contest at the National Sporting Club, in Brooklyn, New York. Diry was from Ireland, where his name was spelled (and pronounced) "Deery." He had won a fight in November, but this was his second loss since then, and he endured three more knockouts early in 1914, before hanging up his gloves for good. Diry's boxing record: boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=73885&cat=boxer New York Times story, December 16, 1913: (The Times calls him a German, and says that he had won several fights, but the record contradicts that statement.) query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9807E...

Hi Wystan. I tend to believe the Diry was indeed German, not Irish, as another NYT link credits him as the German middleweight champion (see his boxrec.com bio). The only source I'm finding that says he's Irish is the info at the top of his boxrec.com record, but I believe that's an error, and I'm also going to guess that whoever compiled his "official" record there got most if not all of the results from the same NYT links we're seeing.
There were also many boxers who were not Irish but fought under Irish names in that era.

"When Victoriano Huerta seized the Mexican presidency in 1913, the United States refused to recognize him. From the Glenaffric and Strathglass [Scotland] website:

THE MILLIONAIRE STALKER
Walter Winans, the American millionaire, who rented nearly 250,000 acres in Glen Strathfarrar, was it’s most famous and most notorious sporting tenant. He also rented land at Fasnakyle, Knockfin and Glens Cannich and Affric. Before stalking was established, deer were driven to the hunters. Winans had gigantic drives, culminating between Lochs Beannacharan and a’ Mhuillidh, which local stalkers considered wholesale slaughter, compared with the skill of stalking. Winans could bring down stags galloping at 100 yards, and once went so far as to paint a white horse dapple-grey - the colour lasted ten weeks and the chemicals kept the midges off!

The Lorillard family fortune was founded on tobacco.

From a 1921 guide to New York City:

The Lorillard Mansion 

Queen of them all and situated in the most charming location of the borough's most beautiful park stands, north of Pelham Parkway, the old Lorillard Mansion, a mass of solid stone. Nowhere do the glades of Bronx Park look lovelier than from its commanding upper windows. With its sixty-eight rooms it is the chief attraction of this delightful natural playground. 

It was erected about 1850 by Pierre Lorillard, and stands today as the home of the Bronx Society of Arts and Sciences, the large parlors being well filled with all sorts of objects, quaint and curious. 

That portion of the extensive Lorillard domain west of the river boasts a splendid hemlock forest, declared to be without an equal anywhere. How fortunate that this family preserved so well the natural glories of their immense estate, so that in our day its magnificent trees and velvety lawns have been appropriately utilized as a Botanical Garden of 250 acres. 

Below the mansion, winding driveways lead to the graceful old Lorillard stables, stone-built and solid, which resemble in their strikingly picturesque setting a chapel rather than a stable. To the south-west, across Pierre Lorillard's famous "Acre of Roses," now the beautiful "Old-fashioned Flower Garden," still rises high above the river's brim the substantial old Lorillard Snuff Mill, whose ancient wheels proved so wonderfully efficacious in producing the immense fortune of their owner. In mansion, mills and wonderfully glorious estate surely old Pierre Lorillard "builded better than he knew" !

No, this is Mrs. Catharine Haverty of New York City, a widow, and the owner and manager of a 60-cab taxicab company. She is attempting to buck a 1913 New York City strike of unionized taxicab drivers by hiring non-union drivers, and has defied threats, to announce that she will ride at the head of her company's parade of vehicles during the strike. The above photo of Mrs. Haverty, with her driver and vigilant bodyguards, is dated the day after the appearance of this New York Times report of November 13, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B04E0D71E3EE233A...

Sally Frances Grant Slaton, wife of the Governor of Georgia (1913-1915). He was the governor who commuted Leo Frank's death sentence. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Marshall_Slaton
pennylrichardsca: Thanks for the additional info. We'll add it to the source data next time we update.

John Slaton, who earlier had served two months as an appointed Governor or Georgia, to fill a vacancy, was elected in his own right and took office on June 28, 1913. Two months later, on August 26, in Atlanta, Leo Frank (in an infamous miscarriage of justice blamed on racial excitement and antisemitism) was found guilty, after trial, of the murder of a young factory employee, Mary Phagan. The verdict became national and international news. Frank's attorneys requested an appeal of the verdict, and excitement was running high in October and November, when Bain's news agency circulated this photo of the new governor's wife to its subscribers. Was this the only photo Bain could locate near to hand? Why Georgia's first lady, and not the Governor? 

After the appeals process, which continued through 1914 and part of 1915, Governor Slaton committed political suicide by commuting Frank's sentence from death by hanging to life imprisonment. But the Georgia mob would not have it; the KKK dragged Frank out of prison and lynched him. Only in 1986 did the state of Georgia grant him a posthumous pardon.

There was no more excitement about the murder of Mary Phagan, than there was over any other grizzly murder of a child in American history. The Leo Frank case became famous, because the organized Jewish community and many of its leaders decided to embrace the case as a cause celebre of anti-Semitism.  

There was NO miscarriage of Justice at the Leo Frank trial, because when Leo Frank mounted the witness stand on August 18, 1913, he made an admission that amounted to a murder trial confession. 

The Leo Frank Admission that Amounted to a Murder Trial Confession:

Now, gentlemen [of the jury], to the best of my recollection from the time the whistle blew for twelve o’clock [noon on Saturday, April 26, 1913] until after a quarter to one [12:46 pm] when I went up stairs and spoke to Arthur White and Harry Denham [on the fourth floor], to the best of my recollection, I did not stir out of the inner office [located at the front of the second floor]; but it is possible that in order to answer a call of nature or to urinate I may have gone to the toilet [in the metal room at the back of the second floor]. Those are things that a man does unconsciously and cannot tell how many times nor when he does it (Leo Frank Trial Brief of Evidence, August 18, 1913).

Franz X. Arens, a composer and conductor, established the "People's Symphony Concerts" in 1900. The organization is still going strong: pscny.org/history.htm

In 1913, the People's Symphony Concerts moved to the venue which remains their principal home, the auditorium of Washington Irving High School, New York:

"In its early years, the series moved back and forth between Cooper Union and Carnegie Hall several times, sometimes offering concerts at both to accommodate the growing audience. A chamber music series was added in 1910, and in 1913 the chamber concerts took up residence in the 1,500-seat auditorium at Washington Irving High School. The school opened that year on what had been the site of the National Conservatory of Music, which Dvorak directed briefly in the 1890's. Except for a brief period in the 1970's, when the concerts moved to Hunter College and Town Hall, Washington Irving has remained the series' principal home. (The current Town Hall series was added more recently, to address the concerns of older concertgoers who preferred daytime concerts.) "

L.H. Bigelow was captain of the Yale football team in 1907-8: www.thecrimson.com/article/1913/11/22/harvard-and-yale-fo... www.thecrimson.harvard.edu/article/1908/4/1/spring-footba... And later president of the Mitchel College Men's League. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940DE3DF173DE633A... This photo caught my eye because the backdrop appears to be the same one in this image: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4525453659/]

A Google images search under "Yale Football," "Yale Football Player," and "Yale Football Portrait" turns up a bunch more of these player pix with that backdrop. The backdrop, or a similar one, with a segment of the Yale fence in the foreground, apparently was in use for portraits from the 1890s up into the 1960s.

Captain of the Yale football team and look how tattered his uniform is...in a portrait.  Of all universities, you'd think that one of the Ivy League schools would have better equipment.  But it just drives home the point of how spoiled we are today.  We live in a disposable society where we'd rather throw something away than repair it.  (And I certainly don't exclude myself from that statement.)

Ah, but he has just left the field after a practice session, and doubtless wants a photo to send back home to New Jersey, to impress his high school sweetheart. The battered duds make him look rugged and heroic. But when you look at his pretty face, you realize that he really doesn't have a scratch on him. [Funny thing, huh? -- the guy was born in New Jersey, but he isn't wearing one!] This is Lucius Horatio "Ray" Bigelow III. Even his name is heroic. Incidentally, it was a tradition at Yale for the team captain to return the following year as the football coach. Bigelow maintained that tradition. Here's a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucius_Horatio_Bigelow

Alexei Nikolaevich (Russian: Алексе́й Никола́евич) (12 August 1904 – 17 July 1918) of the House of Romanov, was the Tsesarevich and heir apparent to the throne of the Russian Empire. He was the youngest child and the only son of Emperor Nicholas II and Empress Alexandra Feodorovna. He was born with haemophilia; his mother's reliance on the starets Grigori Rasputin to treat the disease helped bring about the end of the Romanov dynasty. After the February Revolution of 1917, he and his family were sent into internal exile in Tobolsk, Siberia. He was murdered alongside his parents, four sisters, and three retainers during the Russian Civil War by order of the Bolshevik government, though rumors that he had survived persisted until the 2007 discovery of his and his sister Maria's remains. The family was formally interred on 17 July 1998—the eightieth anniversary of the murder—and were canonized as passion bearers by the Russian Orthodox Church in 2000. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexei_Nikolaevich,_Tsarevich_of_Ru...

HMS A5 was an early Royal Navy submarine. She was a member of Group Two of the first British A-class of submarines (a second, much different A-class submarine appeared towards the end of the Second World War). Like all members of her class, she was built at Vickers Barrow-in-Furness.

Immediately after commissioning she and her tender HMS Hazard travelled to Queenstown, (now Cobh) Ireland . On 16 February 1905 at 10:05 whilst tied up alongside Hazzard an explosion occurred onboard.

Six of the crew were immediately killed by the explosion or died shortly afterwards:

November 9-11, 1913: a blizzard, an ice storm, a gale, a hurricane -- all ravaged the Great Lakes in the area of Cleveland, Ohio. At least 235 sailors were drowned when twleve commercial ships sank in Lake Erie. A brief history of the disaster: www.ohiohistory.org/etcetera/exhibits/swio/pages/content/...

This image, of the Hotel Collinwood, was taken in what was at the time Collinwood village, and what has since been annexed to the city of Cleveland. The hotel was located on the west side of Collamer Avenue (now East 152nd Street), the fourth building north of Collins Avenue (now Saranac Road). The approximate location can be seen in Google Maps. How do I know this? In the plate glass window in the center of the picture, I've noted the name "Collinwood Hotel Restaurant". It can be seen in the center of the inset in this detail of the 1903 Sanborn fire insurance map for the area: The shape of the building in the photo corresponds exactly to the shape of the Hotel Collinwood building on the Sanborn map. The street numbers do not correspond due to a change in the numbering system for the streets that occurred in 1905. Further evidence of the location is provided by this plate from the 1921 Plat Book of the City of Cleveland. It shows the correct profile for the building, and gives the address as 630 - the number shown on the building in the photo. A streetcar is visible, slightly out of focus, at the right edge of the photograph. This corresponds to the streetcar tracks shown on the map in the Plat Book.

IN TUNIC AND SANDALS.; Beautiful Baroness Causes a Stir at Paris Theatre.
Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
June 29, 1913, Sunday
PARIS, June 28. -- A sensation was caused this week in the Russian ballet at the Theatre Champs Elysees by the beautiful Baroness Yele de Guestre, who attended a performance in a Greek costume, her bare feet shod with sandals of white leather and damascened gold and buckled at the ankle with a gold clasp.

Eli Metchnikoff was the first of two Jews, along with Paul Ehrlich, to receive the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1908 for their research on cellular immunity. According to www.stokowski.org/Principal_Musicians_Metropolitan_Opera.htm which has a picture that looks to be of the same man, "Leopold Kramer was born in 1870 in Prague, then part of Austria. He studied at the Prague Conservatory, and became upon graduation, in about 1890 became Concertmaster of the Gürzenich Orchestra of Cologne, Germany. Kramer was then Concertmaster of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw 1892-1894. He was also at some time, perhaps just before coming to Chicago Concertmaster at the St. Petersburg Philharmonic. In 1897, he came to Chicago to join Theodore Thomas's Orchestra. In November, 1909, Kramer became angry at remarks made by the conductor Frederick Stock, and impulsively quit the Orchestra. He quickly regretted his action, but it was too late. Kramer moved to the Chicago Grand Opera, and then became Concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic for one season 1913-1914. Kramer returned to Austria during the summer of 1914, and was apparently blocked from returning, because of the outbreak of World War 1. He was replaced at New York Philharmonic Concertmaster by Maximilian Pilzer. Leopold Kramer was Concertmaster of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra for one season, 1922-1923. Established in New York City, Leopold Kramer taught at the Institute for Musical Arts (later Juilliard) 1920-1924,. In 1924, Kramer returned to Prague to teach, and where he lived at least until 1936. "

One possibility is that this is Mrs. William Cheney Ellis, the former Eleanor Hosea, of Cincinnati. She was murdered by her husband in October 1913. According to "King of the bootleggers: a biography of George Remus, " they had children Eleanor (2) and Violet (6) at the time. See books.google.com/books?id=zmaXU8H3EUgC&pg=PA11&lp...

Bain's copy negative bears the date 3/3/14 -- this was a day or two before the end of Mr. Ellis' trial, when he was sentenced to 15 years in prison, escaping the death penalty by reason of temporary insanity. He got out in 1921. (Bain must have reused the photo in March, 1914 -- his clerk had neglected to date the photo at the time of its first use, in October, 1913.)

Governors and Governors-General 
in Australia have been permitted to choose their own uniform.  This, however is more unusual than most.

Don't forget that the photo was taken in 1913, seven years before he commenced his Aussie exile. He and his lady were probably preparing to attend a costume party (or a pageant), somewhere in England. They stood for their portraits before the same paintings and furniture.

I was making a little joke about the uniform of office for Governors and Governors-General here - in that I didn't really mean that Sir Archibald had used that uniform whilst a Governor of South Australia. But, there was truth in what I said. For example, Sir Isaac Isaacs a distinguished Governor-General in the 1930s who had no military background adopted this uniform: www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/2869624206/ vrroom.naa.gov.au/print/?ID=19495 Including sword: nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn582907 A New South Wales Governor of the 1970s, Sir Roden Cutler, V.C. who had a distinguished military career took it upon himself to adopt a cocked hat for rare ceremonial occasions, although it had never been part of his former military uniform: cas.awm.gov.au/item/REL/18662.006 No matter how ridiculous the uniform, a Governor was well entitled to wear it as the occasion demanded, for example Sir Philip Game, Governor of New South Wales in 1932: www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/2878526846/

Henry Elionsky Swam continuously for over 60 miles. He started from 189th Street and Hudson River and swam to Swinburne Island in the Lower Bay and then from there to Fort Lee, N.J., and from there to Woolworth Building. The judges of the swim judged the distance or mileage to be over 60 miles. This was in August, 1914. Swam from the Battery to Swinburne Island and returned to the Battery, a distance of over 25 miles, with hands and feet shackled. Time, 11 hours and 30 minutes. In November, 1915, swam from Brooklyn Bridge to Bay Ridge, with hands and feet shackled and towing 7 men in a sea dory. The distance was 7 miles, and the time, 3 hours and 40 minutes. Swam from the Battery to Fort Wadsworth in the Narrows with a 200-pound man tied on his back. Distance of 10 miles, and time, 4 hours and 50 minutes. Swam Hell Gate bound in a straightjacket with feet tied with 15 feet of iron chain. Distance, 5 miles; time, 2 hours and 40 minutes. Swam Hell Gate with hands and feet shackled and two men bound on back in November, 1915. Swam from Bay Ridge to the Battery tied in a chair. He made it in 3 hours and 20 minutes. In October, 1913, swam from Battery to within a quarter of a mile of Coney Island in 5 hours and 30 minutes. The distance was 14 miles. At Palm Beach, Fla., hauled a sea dory containing 9 men and carried two more on his back, with his hands and feet shackled, five miles, through a heavy sea, in 2 hours and 50 minutes. www.naturalstrength.com/2009/09/endurance-by-earle-e-lied...

Could have been on October 5, 1913, when he attempted to swim with hands shackled and feet bound from the Battery (southern end of Manhattan Island) to Coney Island. See NYT of Oct 6, 1913 (second piece in this extract) query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B04E3D6163DE633A...

Thank you  pennylrichardsca for giving us more complete information on swimmer Harry Elionsky’s name.  However, Elionsky appears not to have died in the influenza epidemic of 1918. A Boston Globe article (Oct. 14, 1918) states  that Elionsky had not died of influenza, as had been previously reported in an earlier article.  A 1921 New York Times article (June 28, 1921) says that Harry Elionsky announced that he was going to attempt a one hundred mile swim, so he was still alive then.  Swang,  as Elionsky made many stunt swims while shackled, it is hard to know if this is the one that occurred on Oct. 5, 1913.  So we will hold off on the more precise date for now.

Oh!  That's interesting--he's still listed in a lot of "famous victims of the 1918 flu" rolls.  He seems to serve as an example of how even the strongest were felled--because he was clearly a strong healthy guy!  Glad you corrected the error here.

He didn't die during the flu epidemic, he was still swimming into the 1920's. The report of his death was premature and is still reported in error by two recent books. The people of Ulster were pushed to a small coastal strip bordering the Irish Sea. The kingdom changed it's name to Dál Riata. Yet eventually Dál Riata fell under the rule and influence of the Uí Néill. This family, not content with the boundry presented by the sea, launched colonies across the Irish Sea into then Pictish Britain. Thus was Scotland founded, for it was these Uí Néill that the Romans called Scotti, not the original Picts.

Not the Hindenburg, as one might think... There's been zeppelins that caught fire before. This one is likely LZ18: The German Army and Navy purchased 14 Zeppelins, who labeled their aircraft Z 1/2/... and L 1/2/..., respectively. During the war, the Army changed their scheme twice: following Z XII, they switched to using LZ numbers, later adding 30 to obscure the total production. When World War I broke out, the military also took over the three remaining DELAG ships. By this time, it had already decommissioned three other Zeppelins (LZ3 "Z1" included). Five more had been lost in accidents, in which two people had died; a storm forced Navy Zeppelin LZ14 or "L1" down into the North Sea, drowning 14; LZ18 or "L2" burst into flames following an engine explosion, killing the entire crew. (Wikipedia) It also looks like the image is at least rotated 90 degrees, if not upside-down.

17th October 1913, the L 2 was due to have an altitude test.  Because there was a delay in starting one of her engines she remained in the sun and this caused the hydrogen lifting gas to warm too much.  She rose fast to "pressure hight" where gas was vented from valves at the base of the gas cells.  

The released gas mixed with the air in the enclosed keel to form an explosive mixture.  The navy had insisted on fitting windscreens to the engine gondolas which meant that the explosive gas mix reached the hot engines and duly  exploded.  This ignited the main gas cells, one by one, as the airship fell.

Before she hit the ground, another gas/air mixture exploded, scattering debris.  Three badly burned men crawled out of the wreckage but none survived the night.

Paraphrased from "Airshipwreck" Len Deighton and Arnold Schwartzman, Jonathan Cape Ltd, 1978.
