The New York Times, Wednesday, August 18, 1901, Page 13: ARBUCKLE'S FLOATING HOTEL DISMANTLED Lack of Patronage Caused the Company to Go Out of Business. John Arbuckle's Floating Hotel Company has gone out of business, after a brief existence of not quite four weeks. The failure of the scheme is directly due, so it is said, to the unappreciative and conservative spirit of the people of New York and Brooklyn, who preferred the comfort of their homes, even on a hot night, to the promise of a cool night on a sailing vessel out on the lower bay.

Looks like this is from a bit later, though. NY Times Thursday August 27, 1914: FLOATING HOTEL TO CLOSE Notices were posted yesterday in the Arbuckle Floating Hotel, which is the old ship Jacob A. Stamler, moored at the foot of East Twenty-third Street, that the hotel would be closed on Sept. 12 next. The fifty or more young women who live in the hotel were downcast when they read the notice.

Designed by the Architect Ralph Adams Cram, a specialist in the Gothic Revival, the Cleveland Memorial Tower at Princeton University was built in 1911-1913, after the death of former President Grover Cleveland, whom it memorializes. Cleveland had been a resident of Princeton, New Jersey, from 1897, the end of his second term as President, until his death in 1908. He also served as a Trustee of Princeton University. The bells of the carrillon were not added until 1927 -- a gift of the Princeton Class of 1892. The tower was dedicated in a ceremony on October 22, 1913, at which former President William Howard Taft was the principal speaker.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Tower

That initial J probably is Bain's error. Maybe it stands for "Jr." This likely is Charles C. Nott, Jr., former Assistant District Attorney, and the newly-elected judge of the General Sessions court in New York. That would fit with the Bain/LOC photo timeline, which is now posting stuff taken in November, 1913. Here is Nott, in a New York Times story from November 7, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E03EED9113CE633A...

It was probably a "J" for Judge. It is sometime difficult to read the Google News Archive when people are referred to as Judge, Cardinal, Marshall, Governor and Mayor and only a last name. They are assuming the contemporary reader is already familiar with the people in the news, and there is only one person by that name in that time and geographic location. I was able to get his birth date from his passport application from 15 October 1920. tennesseeencyclopedia.net/imagegallery.php?EntryID=E016 from the link Sarah Barnwell Elliott, novelist, short story writer, and advocate of women's rights, was born in Savannah, Georgia, the daughter of Stephen Elliott, a bishop of the Episcopal Church who was a leader in the founding of the University of the South at Sewanee. Her education consisted of private tutoring and some study at Johns Hopkins University in 1886. Though she lived for a time in New York (1895-1902), Elliott's principal home was Sewanee, where she died and was buried. She never married. My guess it was an honorary degree.

"The responsibility of raising her nephews drew Elliott back to Sewanee in 1904, where she continued her energetic support for women's rights as a lecturer essayist, and suffrage leader. These efforts served as the catalyst for Tennessee's becoming the critical thirty-sixth state and the only southern state to ratify the Nineteenth Amendment (1921), which guaranteed women the vote. In 1913 she was awarded an honorary Doctor of Civil Law degree by the University of the South."
-----Southern Local Color: Stories of Region, Race and Gender (2002), p. 232.

This is William C. Gorgas; Bain's photo caption omits his first name. Gorgas was a U. S. Army General, and a military surgeon. Why doesn't Bain call him "General Gorgas," or "Dr. Gorgas?" Gorgas instituted mosquito eradication in Havana during the Spanish American War, and later in the Panama Canal Zone during construction of the canal -- measures that eliminated the scourge of Yellow Fever in those places. history.amedd.army.mil/surgeongenerals/W_Gorgas.html Gorgas receives an honorary degree at Columbia University, June 4, 1913: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3389737397/in/photostream/]

From Wiki

Jules Henri Poincaré (29 April 1854 – 17 July 1912) (French pronunciation: [ˈʒyl ɑ̃ˈʁi pwɛ̃kaˈʁe][1]) was a French mathematician, theoretical physicist, and a philosopher of science. Poincaré is often described as a polymath, and in mathematics as The Last Universalist, since he excelled in all fields of the discipline as it existed during his lifetime.

That's nice, but it was established last week, in comments on an identical copy of this image (posted with last week's batch of LOC photos) that this is not Henri, but Raymond Poincare (1860-1934), the President of France, being welcomed on a visit to Spain by King Alfonso XIII. Alfonso had been Poincare's guest in Paris, several months earlier.

query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9904E2D7133FE633A... MAN IS SHOT DEAD IN CHASE FOR STEER; Frenzied Animal Tears Down Fifth Avenue, Police Shooting from Taxicabs. SEVEN OTHERS SCATTER Wild Bullet Slays a Watchman ;- Waiter Is Wounded ;- All the Beeves Caught or Killed. November 4, 1913, Tuesday A policeman's wild bullet killed a watchman early yesterday morning in a wild cattle chase, which spread consternation in the heart of the city. One lumbering steer seeking to escape pursuit turned into Fifth Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street and, dodging bullets which were fired at it by pursuing policemen, caused such uproar that Fifth Avenue thought that either a gangsters' battle was in progress or a Wild West show had lost its bearings.
Those were the days, eh?

Very interesting report photographys. Thanks and Greetings.

Most people do not know that Mr. Rickey started out as a catcher in 1906 with the Cleveland Browns.  He also played for the New York Highlanders the following year.  In this photo you have uploaded, he was the manager of the Browns. 

Branch Rickey had a lot of interesting ideas, among which was the "farm system" of minor league teams.  Most everyone in baseball respected him, called him "Mr. Rickey", not "Branch."  Not everyone got along with him.  He was a no nonsense person, a strict born again Christian type, never touched a drop of alcohol and never used foul language.  He knew how to get the most from his players and coaches and managers, for as little money as possible.  So, he was known as a penny pincher.  He had an uncanny knack of judging a young player's potential.  I have read some of his scouting notes, and he was uncanny in predicting the baseball futures of many ball players.

Many people think that baseball would never have been integrated without Mr. Rickey, but that is not true.  Bill Veeck was working on getting Satchel Paige and Larry Doby for the Cleveland Indians around the same time.  The apparent hold up at that time, 1946, was Commissioner Happy Chandler who I think was a little skittish about allowing "negroes" into the major leagues, for whatever reason, perhaps having been pressured about it by various owners who knew that many white players were opposed to integration.  At any rate, it is fair to say that Mr. Rickey, The Dodger system, and Jackie Robinson, and the eventual cooperation of Commissioner Chandler, all were factors resulting in the signing of the first Black player in the modern era of the major leagues.

I am fortunate to have known a man who worked in management in the Dodgers system for Mr. Rickey.  

This is a great photo, btw.  One usually sees photo of Mr. Rickey in his usual suit coat and bow tie.
Date on the photo (appears to be written on the back, as it's reversed) is 10/29/13 - so it appears this photo was taken in 1913, not 1910 - his first year as a manager.

John Purroy Mitchel was elected (on a fusion ticket) to succeed Acting Mayor Ardolph Loges Kline. Kline, the head of the Board of Aldermen, had become acting mayor when Mayor William Jay Gaynor died, on September 10, 1913. Kline filled out Gaynor's term until the end of the year.
Election was on November 4, 1913. See www.thehistorybox.com/factual_first/1900s_3.html and query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03E3DF173DE633A...
Thanks to both of you for the additional information.  We'll add the date of the election to the record the next time we update it.
The grandstand at the circus?

No, these are giant political posters, featuring anti-Tammany cartoon drawings. The Tammany tiger symbol was devised by the famous Harper's Weekly cartoonist Thomas Nast, who also invented the elephant and donkey symbols of the Republican and Democratic parties. The tiger in the foreground has the word "Tammany" on a collar around its neck. The posters appear to have suffered an assault by pro-Tammany hooligans.

Eric L. Boetzel, the man in the photograph, was a former deputy Attorney General of New York state, and a former Assistant District Attorney of NYC, who had resigned that office to become assistant manager of the 1913 New York City mayoralty campaign of John Purroy Mitchel, the fusion candidate, who won election.
LOC -- his name was BOETZEL, with a zed, not an ess. Bain at this period had a clerk on staff who was unable to inscribe a proper zee.
Thanks for the info.

In 1912 J. P. Morgan decided to demolish his offices at 23 Wall Street. Demolition started on 30 April, 1913. New offices for the same firm were to be constructed upon the site, shown in the photograph above. From this photograph it appears that the Y.M.C.A. appeal billboard was put up on this prominent position between demolition of the old building and construction of the new. Flickr user TVL1970 has tagged the photograph as 25 Broad Street, so perhaps it also bears that address. See a related photograph "Tearing down Morgan Offices" here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3160168344/ and related photograph "Tearing down Morgan Offices" here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3159334005/

@Bob Meade: TVL 1970 in his tag (now withdrawn) evidently mistook the Wall Street site in the photo for 25 Broad Street, which was then the headquarters of the YMCA (and of the fundraising campaign). [The address "25 Broad Street" appears on the clock dial.] The four million dollar "whirlwind" campaign, for a joint YMCA/YWCA, was the largest fundraiser in world history up to that time. Campaign "clocks" like the one shown here were erected at various strategic locations to keep the project in the public eye. This story in the "New York Times," November 13, 1913, mentions another one: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9501E0D71E3EE2...
you can google earth this intersection and see its distinctive shape

Story of the demolition and new building here: www.nytimes.com/2003/04/20/realestate/streetscapes-j-p-mo... Thanks all for the additional information about this interesting building and site.

David Ignatius Walsh (1872-1947) was a United States politician from Massachusetts. As a member of the Democratic Party, he served in the state legislature and then as Lieutenant Governor (1913-1914) and then as the 46th Governor (1914-1916). His first term in the U.S. Senate (1919-1925) was followed by a brief hiatus from government, after which he was elected to the U.S. Senate four times, serving from 1926-1947. On foreign affairs, he was an consistent isolationist, from his early opposition to U.S. domination of the Philippines to opposing Lend-Lease until the attack on Pearl Harbor. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_I._Walsh

John Nelson Carlisle (1866-1931) — also known as John N. Carlisle — of Watertown, Jefferson County, N.Y. Born in Preble, Cortland County, N.Y., August 24, 1866. Great-grandson of William Carlisle; grandson of Nelson Burdick; son of Catherine Rose (Burdick) Carlisle and William S. Carlisle; married, January 17, 1894, to Carrie C. Brown. Democrat. Lawyer; chair of Jefferson County Democratic Party, 1891-96; secretary of New York Democratic Party, 1898-1905; delegate to Democratic National Convention from New York, 1904. Universalist. Member, Freemasons; Knights Templar. Died July 21, 1931. Burial location unknown. Source: politicalgraveyard.com/bio/carfield-carll.html
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percival_Lowell

In 1913, Lowell announced a new search for "Planet X" -- the astral body which, when finally found years later, was named Pluto (and which astronomers no longer regard as a planet). Lowell (1855-1916) left a million dollars in his will to finance continued work in the search for "X".

Long after his death, studies of photographic plates that had been made by Lowell using his telescope in Arizona disclosed two images of Pluto!

This appears to have been the scene, on November 1, 1913, of a big auction at the Long Island farm of the late New York Mayor William Jay Gaynor, who had died in September. Items at auction included Gaynor's horses and farm animals, and drew a crowd of 1,000.

The J. E. Smith Haddens had an estate called Hempstead Farm, near Hempstead, Long Island, on Meadow Brook Road, not far from the Meadow Brook Hunt Club and polo grounds.

The woman in this photo probably is Mrs. Smith Hadden -- not "Miss." Bain has mistaken her marital status.

A NYT news item from 1899 recalls an earlier adventure of Mrs. J. E. Smith Hadden with a horse and an employee named John Kelly. [The John Kelly in this photo looks too big to have been a jockey.]

"MRS. J. E. SMITH HADDEN IN A RUNAWAY"

"Hempstead, L. I. (April 8) Mrs. J. E. Smith Hadden's pony ran away today. A groom named Kelly was driving her through the village. Mrs. Hadden, who is a member of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club, and an expert horsewoman, jumped from the cart and escaped injury. Kelly could not stop the pony and was thrown out. His shoulder was dislocated. The pony ran into the wagon of George Sessions, and was stopped. The animal escaped injury."

---New York Times, April 9, 1899.

This appears to have been the scene, on November 1, 1913, of a big auction at the Long Island farm of the late New York Mayor William Jay Gaynor, who had died in September. Items at auction included Gaynor's horses and farm animals, and drew a crowd of 1,000. Wealthier than Croesus, John E. Aldred was a New York banker and power company entrepreneur, who later controlled Gillette razors, Gorham silverware, and the U. S. manufacture of Rolls Royces. He funded a lecture series on Engineering Practice at Johns Hopkins University, in Baltimore, where he owned a utility company. The Aldred Building, a skyscraper in downtown Montreal, still bears his name. He owned a 40-room English Gothic mansion on the Long Island "Gold Coast" -- ligoldcoast.com/liprivate.html: "Ormston House, the John E. Aldred estate, was built in 1910. Now used as a monastery, this 40 room mansion is reminiscent of an English country estate. Situated atop a sloping hill, it commands a magnificent view of Long Island Sound. J. E. Aldred constructed this estate at the same time [as], and adjacent to, the former W. D. Guthrie estate, Meudon. Aldred and Guthrie were friends, who together purchased the town of Lattingtown, then demolished all of its homes and businesses to create their estates."

the ship is actually the Good Ship Stamler, closed on Aug 38, 1915 floating hotel, run by the Arbuckle Deep Sea Company query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B00E1DE1138E6...

Nay, it was not so -- the hotel was saved at the last minute, according to a later (August 29, 1915) New York Times story: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9803E0D91739E233A... John Arbuckle, of Arbuckle Coffee fame, had operated the docked boat as living quarters for low income working youths, who paid a pittance for room and board. After his death, his heirs ordered the hotel closed in September, 1913, then relented and granted it a reprieve, which is probably the news that triggered this photo. In 1914 came another closing order; that too was reprieved. Then the kerfuffle in August, 1915. But the relief then was short lived. On November 10, 1915, the Fire Prevention Bureau shut the old vessel down for good, calling it a firetrap. [One reason was that all the doors opened inward.] From a website by a descendant of Stamler, who built the boat: "Fortunately, the thirty-eight girls still living on the Stamler were found new homes on land. Arbuckle’s sisters 'had investigated all the other hotels and found them suitable,' according to the Times, 'and would pay the expenses of moving for each girl.' The vessel’s captain, cook, and other employees were promised new employment. The paper reported that 'many girls who used to live on the Stamler and have moved out because they got married or earned more money, came back for a last look at their old home, to laugh a little and cry a little with the girls who were leaving.' "There are no extant records describing the Stamler’s ultimate fate. It’s rumored that she did ultimately burn in a fire, in 1916, at the foot of North Henry Street, but this is still unsubstantiated."

“Wolf”, the Alsatian, was a relative of Rin Tin Tin, another World War One battlefield survivor. A tongue-in-cheek photo feature in the Perrysburg Journal (Ohio), published June 14, 1917, tells his story: “German ‘Traitor’ Dog is Vernon Castle’s War Prize.” “Vernon Castle’s ‘German traitor’ dog has been the object of keen admiration among friends of the actor since his return to America from the battlefields of France, where he has been doing service with the British Flying Corps. The dog is of the breed used by the Huns for police work and also for Red Cross scout duty. It was originally in the German army, but, being, an especially intelligent animal and vigorously opposed to murderous Kaiserism, it boldly deserted to the English forces in the thick of battle. Now the dog is thoroughly British, so much so that he dotes on making mincemeat of any dachshund he can find. The picture is the first which Mrs. Vernon Castle has had taken with her husband since he came home.” chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87076843/1917-06-14/ed-...

Marv, that's a wonderful story, thanks. Incidentally Susan Orlean (author of "The Orchid Thief") has a new book out, about Rin Tin Tin, the original dog star of the movies, who was discovered as a German Shepherd pup in a nest of newborn puppies in the middle of a WWI battlefield, surrounded by the disasters of war. Susan was interviewed this morning (9/24/2011) on NPR.

Thanks, Wystan.  I read the review of Susan Orlean's Rin Tin Tin book in the New Yorker a few weeks ago.  His master's divorce from a woman who just couldn't compete with him for her husband's affection put me in mind of the joke: "I got a dog for my husband. It was a really good trade!"

At present, I'm immersed to my eyeballs in early 20th century show business history, in hot pursuit of something called "the collie ballet," in which the father of my first wife appeared in 1910 (she died in 1991, and her father, Walter Burke, died in 1966, too soon for me to have met him).  Both the ballet and Mr. Burke were minor features of a smashingly successful musical called "The Top o' th' World," which launched him on a thirty-year theater and vaudeville career.  The wonderful Dolly Sisters' routine, "The Dollys and their collies," was a pale imitation of this act presented many years later.  Walter also happened to be a WWI pilot who was in training in Texas at the same time, or just after, Vernon Castle crashed and died there on a training flight in 1918.

If the January, 1914 on the negative is correct, though, the story of the "German Traitor Dog" would seem to be made up by the press or Vernon C's management, since war didn't break out until August, 1914. It's possible that Irene is holding her pet monkey in her right hand, as she is in this other Bain photo:

I think I figured this out. The 1917 German Shepherd was a different dog. Vernon Castle started a kennel at his country home in Manhasset, NY, and had acquired a pedigreed German Shepherd to show and make available for stud. "TELL MAY BE IN PERIL. Dancers are in France With Their German Shepherd Dog, Vernon Castle, who is now abroad, took the German shepherd dog Tell von Flugelrade with him. The more than ordinarily high trained dog cost Mr. Castle $1,000, that price being paid to L. I. De Winter of the Wlntervlew Kennels at the Long Island Kennel Club show at Sheepshead Bay for the imported son of Frank von Flugelrade and Irma von Flugelrade. Mr. and Mrs. Castle went to France, where they expected to exhibit their dog." N.Y. Sun, 8/26/14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1914-08-16/ed-... This German Shepherd is probably Tell. The scratched out caption about Wolf and Wallop might be from a mistaken later entry on the 1914 negative. "Wallop" is pictured as one of Mrs. Castle's prize-winning[ Brussels Griffon] in a June, 1915 picture: www.corbisimages.com/stock-photo/rights-managed/U28059INP...

There is a nice myth attached to the causeway - in that Finn MacCool (an Irish Giant) built it as a pathway to Scotland in order to kill another giant he had heard about there. As the story goes, when Finn got to Scotland and seen the enormous size of the Caledonian Giant he quickly ran back to the Antrim coast to hide.  The Scottish Giant then came looking for Finn - who in an attempt to hide dressed himself as a baby and hid in a big basket, and asked Finn's wife where he was - she told him Finn was out hunting but would be back soon.  The Giant then noticed the baby and fear came over him - if that was the size of Finn's baby then how much bigger must Finn himself be??? He then made a quick escape, in case Finn was to return, and ran home to Scotland destroying the path behind him as he went.

Funnily the causeway was also used as the backdrop to the final parts of Hellboy 2!

@Shikari - they're basalt columns, formed when the liquid basalt rock hardened under unusual conditions. If you ever get the chance to go, you should - the Giant's Causeway (search on the internet for it) is a truly unmissable sight.....

Sarah Anne, here's a definition of a photochrom print from our Thesaurus for Graphic Materials: "Color photomechanical prints produced lithographically from photographs. The technique was developed in Switzerland in the 1880s by Photoglob Zurich and used until the early 1900s. The caption is often in gold lettering. The prints look deceptively like color photographs unless viewed with a magnifying glass."  Hope this helps.

LOC -- the original caption on the photo reads "Clare" -- not "Claire." So why even mention the incorrect spelling in the LOC title?
The Cliffs of Insanity!

Wystan -- Good question.  We had a choice back in 2000 when we first worked with the Photochrom Collection -- use the caption printed on the picture, or, the title listed in the 1905 Detroit Publishing Company sales catalog. We went with the sales catalog because it had helpful additional information like country names.  

As misspellings or out-of-date names are spotted, we weave the correctly spelled or current names into the titles, prefaced with "i.e."  The published spelling  has been left in the titles to help people working from the old sales catalog find the corresponding images. But, we're beginning to experiment with parking these 'misspellings' and incorrectly identified places in the notes area.

And, Increasingly with new projects, we rely on the captions as they appear in the original images, no matter how incomplete. The spirit of "transcription" helps us represent the images as their creators presented them.  Transcription can also make it easier to retrieve and compare copies of an image in different collections, or to share catalog records among libraries.  Like book cataloging.

Unlike books, though, even transcribed photo titles are still likely to have misspellings and bracketed corrections. We've come full circle.

Thankfully and despite the fact that Oliver Cromwell never actually came to Kerry, this bridge is traditionally known as Cromwell's Bridge. 
It seems more likely that the name is derived from the Irish word for moustache, croimeal. Certainly its shape does resemble a very thick moustache. A unique footbridge made with drywall construction, it has an extremely high arch. In fact, it seems amazing that anyone could actually mount it. The bridge dates from the 17th century and was built by English occupation settlers. Do not attempt to cross it today. A much safer footbridge is further down the road on your left.

There is one bridge by this name in Lancashire in England

This place is called Cobh now and it looks almost exactly the same. It is also the last port ever visited by the Titanic before she headed out into the open Atlantic ocean (April 11, 1912).
Before the spire on the cathedral was built www.flickr.com/photos/36928008@N08/3958853158/

Cobh was the departure point for 2.5 million of the six million Irish people who emigrated to North America between 1848 and 1950. These included Annie Moore and her two brothers – the first immigrants to be processed on Ellis Island in New York. On 11 April 1912 Queenstown was the final port of call for the RMS Titanic as she set out across the Atlantic on her ill-fated maiden voyage. The RMS Lusitania was sunk by a German U-Boat off the Old Head of Kinsale on May 7, 1915. The survivors were brought to the town of Cobh, and over one hundred victims lie buried in the Old Church Cemetery about a mile north of the town. 

The chilling last words of 19-year-old Jeremiah Burke from Glanmire, Co. Cork, were slipped into a bottle not read until a year after his death on the Titanic. Now, the emotional artifact is on display at Cobh Heritage Centre. Using the bottle of holy water that his mother gave to him when she saw him off in Cobh, Burke used one of his very own shoelaces to tie it up and threw the letter overboard. The letter simply reads: "From Titanic, goodbye all, Burke of Glanmire, Cork.”
Closer view in B&W at a very similar date over at the nli:
That's definitely a British protected or second-class cruiser in classic Victorian colors (black, white and buff) in the harbor. Can't figure out which class, though.
Queenstown properly known as Cobh (pronounced "cove") nowadays.

A view from Queenstown to Her Majesty's shipyard at Haulbowline. Founded by Oliver Cromwell as a victualling base for the English Navy. Most of the buildings are built from Limestone quarried from the Island. This view is taken from North to South and also overlooks Roches point Lighthouse, Fort Davis, Fort Camden and the spike Island Star Fort & Prison. The Island has held the Royal Navy, Irish Coastal Marine Service and to date the Irish Naval Service.

Some more information for anyone interested: Saint Finbarre's Cathedral, also spelled Saint Fin Barre's Cathedral (Irish: Ardeaglais Naomh Fionnbarra) is a Church of Ireland cathedral located in Cork City, Republic of Ireland. The site of the cathedral has been a place of worship since the 7th century. The three spires of the cathedral are one of Cork's main landmarks. It is the seat of the Bishop of Cork, Cloyne and Ross, currently Bishop Paul Colton. It is named after Cork's patron saint. A Medieval Cathedral was situated on the site prior to the 18th Century building, but few traces of it are visible. The cathedral was damaged during the siege of Cork in 1689/90, when it came under fire from the nearby Elizabeth Fort. When the steeple was demolished in 1865, a 24-pound cannon was discovered, which is now on display in the cathedral. A small Neo-Classical building was constructed on the site in 1735 by Bishop Peter Browne. It was demolished in 1865 to make way for the present cathedral. The 1735 entrance gate survived the re-building and is still in use. Architect William Burges began work on the present Gothic Revival cathedral in 1862. Construction started on the cathedral in 1865 and in 1870 the unfinished building was consecrated. The towers and spires were finally completed in 1879. Burges gifted a Resurrection Angel, made of copper and gold leaf, which is located on the pinnacle of the sanctuary roof. There is a local superstition which states that if ever the angel falls, it would signify the end of the world. www.flickr.com/photos/mickdunne101/4746188267/

St. Patrick's is the national cathedral of Ireland and one of the more complete medieval buildings in the city.  Dublin rejoices in two cathedrals (this one and Christchurch).  There is no Roman Catholic Cathedral - the Pro-Cathedral near O'Connell Street being designated instead.  The RC church over-reached itself and purchased Merrion Square Park to build one there in the 60s.  In a remarkable display of spine the city fathers refused planning permission for a hideous structure in one of the most complete Georgian Squares in Western Europe.  Given the recent lack of morality of the RC Church it seems unlikely that there will ever be a RC Cathedral.

A great view of the main street in the city.  Apalling damage was done to the street as a result of the Rising of 1916 when a gunboat sailed up the Liffey to the Bridge and fired on the street.  The street was restored afterwards and today looks, if anything, more impressive.  Film of the Rising in 1916 shows new trees having been planted in the centre of the street and these were all removed in the past decade as the architects' department of Dublin City Council decided to 'improve' the street and rebrand it as a boulevard in the French style.  Dubliners were horrified at the loss of the mature London Plane trees which had housed a massive population of wagtails and other birds.  What is striking today in walking the street is the vast diversity of people from all parts of the world who now call Dublin home.

This is the Wellington Monument named for the Iron Duke.  Wellington was born in Ireland and when queried once on whether he considered himself to be an Irishman replied, a man can be born in a stable, but does that make him a horse?  Wellington was one of many in previous centuries who considered themselves British but were of Irish origin.  One of the interesting features of the Good Friday agreement is that this viewpoint, so long sneered at by nationalists, was accepted as being equal to the nationalist one - both North and South.
Wellington's birthplace, a magnificent townhouse on Lincoln Place, is now owned by the National Gallery of Ireland.

Gorgeous!
Trinity College dominates straight ahead.  The street curves to the left to go towards O'Connell Bridge over the river Liffey and Oconnell Street, formerly Sackville.  To the right is Grafton Street.

In the foreground is a statue of King George which was often the subject of attack from Nationalists and Republicans.  Following independence the statue was removed from the street and is usually in storage.  I saw it recently and the impact of many attacks is clearly visible as are the various attempts to restore the work.  Nowadays a charming 1960s fountain of the Four Provinces sits on this site.  As Glamborghini notes the facade dominating the view is that of the University of Dublin, Trinity College.  Trinity or TCD is the second largest and the oldest university in Ireland.  It ranks in the top 50 worldwide and has a venerable history that includes Oscar Wilde, Oliver Goldsmith, Dean Swift, Douglas Hyde, Mary Robinson and Samuel Beckett.  The college prides itself on being unorthodox and a place where not being part of the crowd is seen as an asset.  In recent years the college has expanded and grown and a greater focus on pulling in international students and talent as well as world class research has dominated.  Also the university has opened up it's Old Library to visitors so they can see many of the greatest Irish treasures including a Proclamation of the Republic and the greatest treasure of the Celts, the Book of Kells.  Not to be missed either is the Douglas Hyde Gallery, named for Ireland's first president and an institution for cutting edge art.  If you ever get to Dublin try and get a student to show you round the college.

Comments with photo of Trinity College in College Square from National Library of Ireland discuss dating clues. Apparently the last horse-drawn tram ran in 1901 and the first electric tram was in 1896. This picture shows no sign of lines for electric trams. Also, the other photo shows a style of electric lamp outside Trinity College that was apparently used between 1892 and 1903. So the photo used as the basis for the photochrom seems likely to be from before 1892.

Technically this is a fjord rather than a bay.

It's known locally as Killary Harbour and as Kevin states resembles a Fjord.  As a past student of geography I have sat and listened to distinguished professors argue as to whether it really is a Fjord.  The general consensus is that it would be one if it were in the Nordics but as it is not then it is Fjord-like.  Don't you love the pedanticism of academia?  I remember in 1992 sitting on the edge of the site having a Mars bar and watching the beautiful vista when much to my surprise a submarine emerged from the Harbour.  It's well known amongst locals that the UK likes it's nuclear subs to practise in the harbour despite the fact that Ireland is a nuclear free zone.

Alert!  The meeting of the waters is in avoca, county wicklow!!!!!!!!!
Maybe there are two meetings of the waters, because there is certainly one in Killarney.

Actually this is the Meeting of the Waters, where the Upper and Lower Lakes meet near Muckross Peninsula.  A wonderful site made even more so by the existence of a superb cake shop nearby.  Killarney hosts Ireland's largest National Park which came to the nation through American generosity.  In my humble opinion the lakes, the trees, the incomparable wildlife and the sense of remoteness make a landscape that is truly magical.  The best way to see it is with a compass, a map and lots of rain clothes and a big wooly jumper.  Stunning countryside.

Thanks doctorbob, for the additional information about this location.  It certainly is a beautiful spot, even before you get to the cake shop.  We'll add this information to the title the next time we update the record.
www.panoramio.com/photo/42020829
literary gallery
Great Picture. Good to see it hasn't changed much!

Golden eagles once nested on the crag and the last pair were shot in the years up to 1918.  Today the site is part of the Killarney National Park and a wilderness nature reserve.  The Rangers hope to re-introduce the eagle to the site and have made great strides in restoring the landscape which has been attacked by Rhododendron ponticum which had been introduced as a garden plant but escaped.  I have sat on this mountain many times and watch the clouds scud by and fish jump in the lake.

Ross Castle is one of the treasures of the Killarney National Park.  The castle has been restored by the Irish state and can be visited in the Summer.  I love the work that has been done on it and the sense that it retains its character.  Well worth a visit.

Thanks!   The 1905 sales catalog we used to provide the title information lists the county as "Limerick."  We'll need to be more skeptical of the publisher's information.

You might also be careful about the Derry versus Londonderry designations (although chances are you will offend either way)!  The Royal Irish Academy, a cross-border institution, and the oldest research body in Ireland decided after much discussion to call the city, Derry and the county, Londonderry.  Politicians and locals all split in different ways.  Originally designated Doire na Calgach in the 6-7th centuries the city over time became Doire and further Anglicized to Derry.  Doire being Irish for oakwood.  With the plantation of the area by merchants from London in the 16th and 17th Centuries the name became Londonderry and so the battles began as to what to call the place.  The local radio station in an effort to reduce tensions calls this provincial town, Stroke City.
Thank you doctorbob, for the additional information.  We may just leave it as is for now, and see how others respond.

The story of the SS Morro Castle on Wikipedia. Thanks Wystan - the picture looked right, but I didn't check the dates. Stern view of the Morro Castle in Vera Cruz, 1905 Forward staircase.
Morro Castle (1900) (Official Number 93055) Laid down for Plant Line in 1899; launched for Ward Line as MORRO CASTLE in 1900; in service from 1900 to 1924. After a long career as the line's record-breaking speed queen, she was laid up in Brooklyn in 1924 pending sale. Bought by an Italian scrap yard a year later, she made her last voyage across the Atlantic under the Italian flag. Her scrapping was completed in 1926.

Musebrarian, you have the wrong ship. 

The earlier "Morro Castle," built in 1900, was in the news in October, 1913, when its seizure during the Mexican Revolution precipitated an international incident. Here's the story, found via a Google search:

U.S. SHIP IS HELD 

Mexican Gunboat Has Guns Trained on Her Bow. 

Mrs. John Lind is Aboard 

"Morro Castle" of the Ward Line, is Detained in Vera Cruz Harbor. 
The steamship Morro Castle of the Ward Line is holed up in Vera Cruz harbor with the guns of a Mexican gunboat trained on her bow. On board are Mrs. John Lind, wife of President Wilson's envoy to Mexico, many other American passengers, and mail for the United States. 

Captain Huff, the vessels' commander has been cited to appear tomorrow before a local judge to answer a criminal charge. What the charge is has not been told, and the Mexican authorities have not disclosed its nature.

Mr. Lind, who saw his wife go on board the Morro Castle, has sent a vigorous cablegram of protest to Secretary of State Bryan, and to Minister of Foreign Affairs Mojano in Mexico City.

The Morro Castle has been preparing to steam for two days. It was announced last night that Mrs. Lind would be among the passengers. All passengers were aboard this morning and the vessel was in shape to clear when word was sent out to the vessel that clearance papers had been returned by officers of the port. The pilot was warned not to go aboard.

Captain Huff, with local representatives of the line, immediately took steps to learn the cause of the holding up of the vessel, and then Captain Huff was served with the citation. 

While these things were taking place ashore, the Mexican gunboat Zaragosa steamed from her anchorage in the shadow of the Island Fortress and took its position just off the bow of the Morro Castle. 

(October 23, 1913)


US AND MEXICO SITUATION OMINOUS 

President Expected To Issue Ultimatum Warning Foreign Warship to Keep Away. 
Developments at a few hours today in the relations between the United Stares and Mexico emphasized a gravity of affairs more ominous than at any time since President Wilson's administration began. Absolute silence was the order in official quarters.

The release of the Ward Liner Morro Castle after peremptory demands by the United States terminated a delicate situation. Orders were in preparation to the commanders of American warships lying of Vera Cruz to (illegible) upon her release.

(October 24, 1913)

Born in Chicago, the daughter of a Chicago detective (son of an immigrants from Portugal) and a mother of Irish descent, she began her career as a singer in 1900, and went on to great success in the United States,  London, Paris, Berlin, Australia, and New Zealand.  She married an Australian doctor, William O'Hara and retired from the stage when he went to Shanghai in the 1920s.  When the Japanese invaded China, their house outside the Western settlement was burned down.  Dr. O'Hara died in 1941 in part as a consequence of the fire.  May was, along with remaining westerners, twice placed in Japanese camps.  Although she was repatriated to the America in 1943, she was a broken woman.  She died 
of the effects of malnutrition in 1948 in a Chicago charity ward, even though there still De Sousa family members in the Chicago area, who said they were unaware that she had returned to America.  A tragic end to one of America's too little known stars of the stage.

The Seattle Daily Times, Saturday Evening,November 1, 1913, Page Three, Courtesy of Genealogy Bank (picture of couple included with article) Devereux Milburn, Crack Polo Player, Weds Sport-Loving Miss Nancy Steele New York, Nov. 1 – The little Episcopal church at Westbury, L.I., was the scene today of the wedding of Miss Nancy Steele and Devereux Milburn, the crack polo player who was the star of the American polo team in England in 1909 and one of the most notable defenders of the cup at the International contest in this city a few weeks ago. The marriage ceremony which was witnessed only by a few friends and relatives of the couple, was followed by a reception at Sunridge Hall, the country residence of the bride’s parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Steele. A special train from New York carried many guests to the reception and the hunting set of Long Island was well represented. The news of the engagement in June came as a surprise, as few outside of the immediate families of the young couple knew that a deeper sentiment than a mutual interest in sports existed between them. Miss Steele’s father is a member of the firm of J.P. Morgan & Co. Milburn is a member of the Meadowbrook, the Aero and the Racket and Tennis Clubs. He was graduated from Oxford in 1903 and from Harvard in 1906. He was star of the American polo team in England in 1909 and again in 1910 and distinguished himself in the last international series. He has long been noted for his daring horsemanship.
Thanks for the information about the event (and for including your source!).  It will enable us to update the description more precisely.

complex lineage and romances, her name is Alexandra On 15 October 1913, Princess Alexandra married Prince Arthur of Connaught at the Chapel Royal, St. James's Palace, London. Prince Arthur of Connaught was the only son of Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn, the third eldest son of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert and thus a younger brother of her maternal grandfather King Edward VII as. As such, Arthur and Alexandra were first cousins once removed. This was only the second marriage to occur between a Prince and Princess of the United Kingdom (the first being Prince William Frederick, Duke of Gloucester and Edinburgh and the Princess Mary). After their marriage, Alexandra was generally referred to as HRH Princess Arthur of Connaught, Duchess of Fife. This followed the tradition of a wife taking the style and title of her husband. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Alexandra,_Duchess_of_Fife

Salvation Army General Bramwell Booth and his sister, Eva, were paraded through the streets of New York during the SA's big convention, in November, 1913: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4627035426/] 1500 officers of the Salvation Army in America, assembled in New York City for a convention, were visited by General Bramwell Booth from England, the S.A.'s international head. Bramwell had become the second general of the Salvation Army after the death of his father, General William Booth, in 1912. While in New York, Bramwell Booth also visited his sister Eva, head of the United States' branch of the Army, and his brother, General Ballington Booth, the head of the Volunteers of America, an organization that had broken away from the Salvation Army, 17 years earlier. Bramwell Booth (1856-1929) was the second General of the Salvation Army, succeeding his father, William Booth, founder of the organization. Bramwell's sister, Evangeline (Eva) Booth (1865-1950), became the Army's fourth General (1934-39). A naturalized U. S. citizen, Eva was the Army's Commander of the United States from 1904 to 1934. These photos, dated November 26, 1913 (the day before Thanksgiving), show the parade of Salvation Army faithful who accompanied Bramwell to the docks that morning to see him off for England aboard the "France," a ship of the French Line. New York Times story, November 25, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=2&res=9C03E...

From www.indiancanyon.org/pics/carlislebios.html "Pedro "Pete" Calac came to the Carlisle Indian School November 16,1908. The son of Fransisco and Felicidad Molino Calac, he was broughtto the school from Fall Brook, California at the age of 15. Weighing117 llbs with a height of 68" at the time of his arrival, Calac enteredgrade 3 after 36 months of previous schooling at the Rincon Day School(1899-1903) and the Fallbrook District School (1903-1904). Two ofPete's brothers had died of typhoid fever and he had a brother and twosisters living in 1908. Calac left the Carlisle Indian School in June 1911 for home inFallbrook. He asked to return to Carlisle and was re-enrolled September22, 1912. There is a great deal of correspondance in his student fileat the National Archives, and there are references to him in theCarlisle Indian School newspapers during the years he played football atthe school. In 1915, he was captain of the team. After being accepted into the Ford Motor Company's training program inDetroit, Michigan in 1915 Calac worked for Ford until November 11,1916. About 50 Carlisle boys participated in this program. According to his obituary, Pete Calac passed on January 30, 1960."

Although not a college, the Carlisle (PA) Indian Industrial School had a football team from 1895 until 1917, and occasionally played the "Big Three" college football teams of that era -- Harvard, Yale and Princeton -- as well as Pennsylvania. The "Indians" never beat Yale or Princeton, but they were victorious over Harvard once or twice, and several times conquered Penn.

Carden was a British diplomat whose career was focused on Latin America. From his entry at thepeerage.com: thepeerage.com/p36306.htm#i363060 "Sir Lionel Edward Gresley Carden was born on 15 September 1851. He was the son of Reverend Lionel Carden and Lucy Lawrence Ottley. He married Anne Eliza Lefferts, daughter of John Lefferts, on 15 February 1881. He died on 16 October 1915 at age 64, without issue. "Sir Lionel Edward Gresley Carden was educated at Eton College, Eton, Berkshire, England. He was Vice-Consul at Havana in 1877. He was British Commissioner of Mixed Claims Commission, Mexico between 1885 and 1889. He was Consul-General to Cuba between 1898 and 1902. He was Minister at Havana between 1902 and 1905. He was Minister at Guatemala between 1905 and 1911. Between 1911 and 1913 Nicaragua and EI Salvador. He held the office of Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador between 1911 and 1913. He was invested as a Knight Commander, Order of St. Michael and St. George (K.C.M.G.) in 1912. He was Minister in Mexico in 1913. He was Minister in Brazil in 1914."

LOC --- the title is defective: The abbreviation for "Deputy" needs a "y" added; otherwise the reader mistakes the word as "Department."

Three "r's" belonged in the old one room schools -- not in the word "Sheriff."

In 1906, Harry K. Thaw pulled a gun, fired three shots, and murdered the noted architect Stanford White, in the roof garden atop New York City's old Madison Square Garden [which White had designed], in full public view of a partygoing crowd. He was found insane, and committed to the Mattewan State Hospital for the Insane, in Fishkill, New York. In 1913, Thaw escaped from Mattewan, and met a confederate who drove him north across the New Hampshire border into Coaticook, Quebec, where he spent several weeks. After extradition from Canada, he was held briefly in New Hampshire, pending his return to the custody of the State of New York. After another trial, in 1915 he was adjudged to have been restored to sanity, and set free.

In September, 2007, Prince Albert II of Monaco dedicated the new Monaco ambassador's residence on Wyoming Avenue in Washington, D. C., in a colorful ceremony attended by an actor costumed as the legendary Buffalo Bill Cody, recalling the 1913 American visit of the prince's great-grandfather (and namesake), who was hosted by Buffalo Bill on a hunting expedition near Cody, Wyoming, that lasted for several weeks. Among other fauna, the first Prince Albert (then Monaco's reigning monarch) killed a black bear and an elk. He also expressed a wish that he could serve as Mayor of Cody, Wyoming -- had he not already been burdened with other duties back in Monte Carlo.

During an 80th anniversary visit in 1993, Albert II (whose mother was the American actress Grace Kelly) toured the site in Wyoming, which is near the east entrance of Yellowstone Park. Although crumbling, Buffalo Bill's old log hunting lodge still stands, and is now a tourist attraction; a dinner for Albert II was held inside.

Multiple scandals attached to this one. Annabel Angus True Alexander French, Lady de Freyne, was born in Scotland, daughter of an innkeeper. She was working at a hotel in London when she met her third husband, Captain Arthur Reginald French, the 5th Baron de Freyne of Coolhaven (1879-1915)--they married in 1902. Her origins weren't widely known until Lord de Freyne disappeared in 1905, on a visit to New York. He apparently joined the US Army "to gain experience of the world," and sometimes sent her letters over the years, from various American cities. He died in battle during WWI. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_French,_5th_Baron_de_Freyne Not much later, Lady Annabel's troubled son from her first marriage, Major Ronald True (b. 1891) was convicted of killing a young woman, Olive Young (aka Gertrude Yates). He had a history of other crimes, including forgery in the US, and desertion from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. True was found insane and placed in an asylum instead of being executed as he was originally sentenced. He died in 1951. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_True Annabel Angus French died in 1962.

Fred Merkle of the New York Giants, also known as "Bonehead Merkle" for a grievous mistake that enabled the Chicago Cubs to win the National League pennant and the 1908 World Series (the last time the Cubs ever won it): en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Merkle "Merkle's Boner": en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkle's_Boner

1863-1946. A native of Ireland, Governor (1911-15) John K. Tener of Pennsylvania was deep into baseball. He had been a professional ball player for Chicago, and even while Governor he also served as President of baseball's National League. He is shown here with his wife, Harriet, whom he married in 1889. She died in 1935. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_Tener

Wystan,

Thanks for the additional information on Gov. Tener and his wife, and for providing the date from the side of the negative. 

It turns out this is one of those cases we find where the date on the negative is not the same as the date of the event shown. This is Gov. Tener and wife Harriet at Game 2 of the 1913 World Series between the Philadelphia Athletics and New York Giants, which took place on Oct. 8, 1913, rather than Oct. 9, 1913 as noted on the negative. (Game 2 took place at Shibe Park in Philadelphia, PA while Game 3  took place the next day at the Polo Grounds in Brooklyn, NY. This photo shows Shibe Park based on the seating and other related photographs.)  

We'll update the description with more detail when we work on this record.

It appears to have been the case, frequently if not invariably, that Bain's crew would date the negatives on the day that prints were made to be sent to subscribers; in the case of breaking news, this often involved a one-day time lag.

On November 19, a few weeks after the photo was taken, Governor Tener accepted appointment as President of baseball's National League. The appointment was ratified by a convention of National League team owners in New York City, December 9 and 10, 1913:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4605960693/]

I had forgotten that the Polo Grounds were also known as Brush Stadium, named after John Brush. 

The Polo Grounds had the deepest center field ever in major league baseball.  

Not only did photographers wear ties and hats, so did men in the crowd.  This was standard dress at a ball park all the way up until about 1960.  All of a sudden, men stopped wearing fedoras and straw hats to the park.  At some point in the sixties, guys started wearing ball caps, and stopped wearing ties.

Note to all - next time you start whining about how your need a different camera, lens, filter, computer, and/or etc. think of these guys.  They wore suits to the game, focused their cameras manually, figured their own exposers, and could take fewer shots in a minute than you could in a second.  And they still managed to get some amazing photographs.  Imagine what they could do with a modern camera - probably whine that they also need that new 17 - 35 mm zoom...

From Wikipedia: "The National Commission was the ruling body of professional baseball starting with the National Agreement of 1903, which made peace between the National League and the American League ... It consisted of three members: the two League presidents and a Commission chairman, whose primary responsibilities were to preside at meetings and to mediate disputes." 

The commissioners in 1913 were: August "Garry" Herrmann, owner of the Cincinnati Reds (president), American League president B. Bancroft "Ban" Johnson, and National League president Thomas J. Lynch.

Arthur Reynolds was president of the Continental and Commercial National Bank of Chicago in the 1920s.  His brother George M. Reynolds was also a banker.

But the Bain photo agency's focus was on news pix related to New York, not Chicago -- and the LOC is currently posting material on Flickr that comes from Bain's 1913 photostream. This is more likely to be Arthur Reynolds, the Broadway actor, who had the role of "Blinker" in a 1913 drama called "The Marriage Market," which opened in New York on September 22, 1913, and continued for 88 performances (in two venues, successively) before closing in December of that year.

Maybe, but.... The banker Arthur Reynolds reported into the New York Times in July 1914 about business conditions in Des Moines (at the time he was president of the Des Moines National Bank), as part of a roundup of regional bankers: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F03EFDB143AE633A... And in 1913, he gave an address to the Academy of Political Science in New York, titled "Centralization of Banking and Mobilization of Reserves." It was published in Proceedings of the Academy of Political Science in the City of New York Vol. 4, No. 1 (Oct., 1913): 118-126. So it seems two different men named Arthur Reynolds were making news in New York City in the fall of 1913.

The National Conservation Exposition was an exposition held in Knoxville, Tennessee, United States between September 1, 1913 and November 1, 1913.[ The exposition celebrated the cause of bringing national attention to conservation activities, especially in the Southeastern United States.] The fair was held in what is now Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. Inspired after the successes of a pair Appalachian Expositions in both 1910 and 1911, civic leader sought to bring greater national exposure to the community an exhibition in 1913. In 1912 at the National Conservation Congress convention, the organization endorsed the conservation fair site to be located in Knoxville. The National Conservation Exposition Company was established and funded by the Tennessee legislature with passage of the Senate Bill #1, Chapter 19 of the general appropriation bill passed during the 58th General Assembly. Additional federal funding was secured for the fair by May 1913. Although a national exhibition, it primarily focused on the natural resources and environments of the South. The two month exhibition drew over one million visitors, with nine major and six smaller buildings constructed on-site to house its exhibits and demonstrations en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Conservation_Exposition

New York Chief Appelate Court Judge Edgar M. Cullen presided over the impeachment trial of New York Governor William Sulzer, in 1913. (In the final vote, Judge Cullen cast his ballot against conviction, but Sulzer was convicted anyway -- the only New York Governor ever removed from office by impeachment. Sulzer had campaigned as a reform governor, and once in office, barged ahead with his reform program, in defiance of Tammany Hall's boss Murphy. So Murphy called his minions to impeach Sulzer, using misuse of campaign funds as a pretext. Here, from 2006 is a tidy NYT recap of the whats and wherefore's of Sulzer's impeachment: www.nytimes.com/2006/10/30/nyregion/30impeach.html

From flagspot.net/flags/fr-14-tr.html "In Normandy, the "industry" of sea bathing started in summer 1824 when the duchess of Berry came to Dieppe with a rich and brilliant court. Under the Second Empire (1852-1870), however, Dieppe was abandoned by the jet-set, and Trouville, located in a less windy environment, was elected "Queen of the Beaches". In fact, the local development of Trouville started in the 1830s, when the English fad of sea bathing was imported to Normandy. The oldest advertisement for Trouville dates back to 1837, in the local newspaper Le Pays d'Auge. Sea bathing was strictly regulated by a municipal decree in 1857: the beach was divided into three sectors, those for women's and men's bathing being separated by a mixed sector. The swimmers had to change their clothes in beach huts provided by the municipality, whereas rich people had "bathing machines" on casters. The railway station of Trouville-Deauville was inaugurated in 1863; the journey from Paris to Trouville-Deauville lasted 5 hours. In 1868, a center for hydrotherapy was built in the gardens of the city hall. Deauville, built from scratch in 1859 by duke of Morny, Napoléon's III half-brother, attracted several of the posh customers of Trouville. The concurrence of Deauville, however, did not alter too much the fame of Trouville. In 1906, the tourist guide Joane mentioned "big horse races, international regattas, polo, clay pigeon shooting and the Eden-concert theater" in Trouville. The Hôtel de Paris had for regular customers the famous actresses Sarah Bernhardt (1844-1923) and Réjane (1856-1920) and the artistic jet-set of Paris."

Eminent British physicist. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oliver_Lodge
In 1913, Lodge was President of the British Association, an organization of scientists there.

As well as making practical inventions, such as the spark plug, he studied telepathy and psychic phenomena. He was in the news around 1913 because he was giving speeches about his belief that personality survived after death and expected that a clear demonstration was close. For example, see NYT of 9/10/1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E0DB123FE633A...

It was a challenge I couldn't resist, so I decided to put Lodge's immortality theory to the test this very morning. Imagine my astonishment when I was able to hold a telepathic conversation with him that lasted nearly thirty minutes! (He asked me not to reveal the details.)

She was an actress who died in the influenza epidemic of 1919.

She appears to have been famous for her striking sense of fashion--do a google image search to see more examples. And her wikipedia entry indicates a flair for other kinds of artifice as well... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaby_Deslys Other tidbits--she died in part because she refused to allow surgeons to operate freely on her severely infected throat, for fear they'd leave scars; and her deathbed was purchased as a prop for Hollywood films, and appears in "Sunset Boulevard" as Norma Desmond's bed.

A Parisian, she came to New York in November 1913, but she might have been in the news because in 1910 she had been a flame of King Manuel -- who was married on September 4, 1913. See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4332823938/ According to Wikipedia, he gave her some very expensive pearls.

A Bain/LOC portrait of Mrs. Harrison, solo:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4332816218/in/photostream/]

Harrison's first wife was California railroad and mining heiress Mary Crocker, married on June 7, 1900. She died five years later in an automoblie accident leaving Harrison to raise two small daughters. Harrison would marry and divorce five more times to: Mabel Judson Cox, Elizabeth Wrentmore, Margaret Wrentmore and Doria Lee. Maria Teresa, a young Filipino woman, outlived Harrison. One of Harrison's daughters by his first marriage was Barbara Harrison Wescott (1904-1977). While living in France, she worked closely with other American expatriates in the literary world. She and Monroe Wheeler established Harrison of Paris, a press publishing limited-edition literary paperbacks. From 1930 to 1934, Harrison of Paris published thirteen titles, including two new works by Glenway Wescott, Wheeler's longtime companion. In 1934, shortly before Barbara Harrison married Glenway's brother Lloyd Wescott, the press relocated to New York, where it published a final title, Katherine Anne Porter's Hacienda. She continued her patronage of the arts throughout her life and was a noted collector of artwork. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Burton_Harrison

THIS IS NOT Mrs. Francis Burton Harrison (Mary Crocker). She died in 1905. Also the child in the sailor suit is not Barbara Harrison Westcott, who was born in 1904 and the younger of the two Harrison daughters.

alanh71188:

Agreed! Since this photograph is dated May 1, 1914, it is more likely that this is Mr. Harrison's second wife, Mabel Judson Cox.  (It's important to note that some of the dates on Bain photographs are later than the actual day the photo was taken, but it seems rather unlikely that they would have acquired a photograph of the first Mrs. Harrison nine years after her death in 1905.) He married Cox in 1907 and they divorced in 1919.  I was not able turn up a photograph identified as Mabel Judson Cox for comparison.

Barbara Harrison ( Wescott)  would have been around ten years old at the time of this photograph.  The second Mrs. Harrison did have a son by her first husband, and there was a younger Harrison daughter, Virginia, so it's pretty difficult to be sure of the identity of the children here.  

If there had not been a total of six Mrs. F. B. Harrisons, positive identification would be a bit simpler!  

Thanks to everyone for your contributions!

While J. H. Choate was U. S. Ambassador to Britain (1899-1905), Henry White served as the embassy secretary. But who was Austen?

It's Austen G. Fox (Austen George Fox, 1849-1937, according to www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n85-363486), a lawyer who was candidate for District Attorney in 1897 (query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F20B1FFA385416...) The New-York tribune., June 01, 1902, Page 4 (with photo) says that he was Vice-President of the Harvard Club in 1902. The sun., January 24, 1915, FIFTH SECTION, Page 9, last column ("NOVEL INSURANCE POLICY A MEMORIAL OF R. W. GILDER") mention him together with Joseph H. Choate.

They married on September 27, 1913, and are shown here embarking on their honeymoon voyage to Europe. He was a titled Englishman, noted for his athletic prowess; she an American beauty, called the most beautiful girl in America. But after three years he ignored her, they parted, he was drinking heavily, she wrote letters of complaint, they were divorced . . . .
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4276924554/] en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_baronets

To no one's surprise, the Bain News Agency has misspelled the name of New York State Senator Thomas H. Bussey. On January 24, 1913, Senator Bussey introduced two pieces of legislation that would strengthen the regulation of taxicab drivers and other professional chauffeurs, to ensure that members of the public would not find themselves being transported to and fro by convicted criminals: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9B07E...

A paragraph from a biographical compendium of eminent politicians, now online, supplies some info about Senator Thomas Bussey's unblemished career:

"Bussey, Thomas H., 

"State senator, manufacturer, of Perry, 
N. Y., was born Troy, N. Y., Feb. 25, 1857; son Esek Bussey, 
stove manufacturer of Troy and Chicago, descendant George 
Bussey, who settled in Calvert Co., Md., from England, 1636, and 
Capt. Bennett Bussey, who organized the Silver Grays, Berk- 
shire Co. militia, during Revolution ; educated Mt. Anthony Sem[inary]., 
Bennington, Yt, ; Troy Acad[emy]., Rensselaer Poly[technic]. Inst[itute]; married [at] Shelbyville, Ky., 1900, Bertha M. De Epping-Housen ; children: 
Beatrice Della-Porta. Engaged in [manufacturing] business, after period of travel; now engaged in m[anufacturing]. Pres[ident of the] village of Perry [NY] during installation of water works and adoption of sewer system; represented town on County Board of Supervisors, four years, and chairman 1910; elected to State Senate, 1910; re-elected, 1912. App[ointe]d comm[isione]r of Panama Exp[ositio]n 1915, for State of N. Y. ; member of the Judiciary Com[mittee] and Com[mmittee] on Miscellaneous Corp[oratio]ns. Shriner, Elks, Moose, I. 0. 0. F. Address : Perry, N. Y."
Thanks Wystan.  We'll make the correction to the record based on your research. But I'll have to use the qualifier "probably" as I can't find another image of Senator Bussey to confirm the identity.

Subject: Sen. T.H. Bussey post

Wystan -
I just wanted to thank you for taking the time to correct the spelling error the Bain News made in identifying a picture of my great-great Uncle Sen. T.H. Bussey taken on the steps of the NY Capital Building in Albany, NY in 1913. I had been researching my Mother's family geneaology when I came across the picture of Sen. Bussey a couple of years ago and had no idea of how to correct the spelling mistake. Thank you for noting the error and requesting that the Library of Congress set the record straight. Please let me know if there is anything I can do to substantiate that you provided the correct spelling of the Bussey surname with the Library of Congress. Again, I thank you for your attention to the details of history. 

Best Regards - Ellen Doody edoodypdx@gmail.com

New York state senator Edgar Truman Brackett, and his law partner, Hiram C. Todd. In 1913, both were counsel to the Board of Impeachment which ousted New York Governor William Sulzer.

Brackett was the linchpin of Republican power in Saratoga County, New York. Todd, also a resident of Saratoga Springs, was not active in politics.

The building behind them is, I surmise, the New York State Capitol.

New York state senator Gottfried Wende. Early in September, 1913, the press learned that Wende, an ardent supporter of New York Governor William Sulzer in the impeachment proceedings against him, may have been influenced by the fact that his son, George B. Wende, received a salary from the Sulzer organization, for labors unspecified.
I added him to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_H._Wende

In 1914, Hamilton Wright Mabie (1846-1916) wrote a seven-page booklet report [available online] for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, titled: "Educational Exchange with Japan -- A Report on Observations Made in 1912-1913." Mabie also published a book in 1914, called "Japan Today and Tomorrow." [This also may be read online.]

LOC note misspelling: Soyeda, not Soveda "Juichi Soyeda (添田 壽一 Soeda Juichi?, September 15, 1864 – July 4, 1929) was a Japanese lawyer, senior civil servant and academic economist." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juichi_Soyeda In 1913, he visited the United States as representative of the Tokyo Chamber of Commerce, in connection with the California Alien Land Law of 1913 together with Tadao Kamiya.
Russell: Lindsay Russell, President of the Japan Society since 1910, see www.japansociety.org/resources/content/9/7/8/documents/Ce..., page 17

LOC note misspelling: Kamiya, not Kamita Tadao Kamiya, chief secretary of the chamber of commerce of Tokio in 1913, see The Ogden standard., June 20, 1913, 4 o'clock p.m. City Edition, Page 10, 4th column, "WILSON RECEIVES JAPANESE PARTY".

LOC note misspelling: Okazaki, not Okazari Kiujiro Okazaki, a member of the Japanese Parliament, came to the USA in June 1913, see u.o. New-York tribune., June 24, 1913, Page 2, with photo The Salt Lake tribune., June 23, 1913, Page 5, 4th. column, "RIDICULES IDEA OF JAPAN'S FIGHTING US"

Ichinomiya: Reitaro Ichinomiya, assistant of the General Manager K. Imanishi of the Yokohama Specie Bank in New York in 1908, see www.archive.org/stream/japaninnewyork01anra/japaninnewyor.... He is still in the same bank in 1915, see query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F50817F93A5C13...

Thanks for all of your hard work identifying these people, B-59.  We will definitely add some of the information to the record when we update. Have you any thoughts about why all of these men would be sitting together?  The date seems to be sometime in June 1913.

I found at last an article in The New York Times, June 27, 1913 which says there was a luncheon, given by the Japan Society of New York at the Hotel Astor on June 26, 1913. The meeting was about the situation of the Japanese in Calfornia (see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Alien_Land_Law_of_1913). All persons in the photo above are mentionned in the article, plus several others. Russel is obviously not - as I supposed first because of a certain similarity - Bertrand Russel, but Lindsay Russel, the President of the Japan Society.
Thanks so much for your perseverance, B-59. This information will add a good deal to the record.  We will add some of it the next time we update.

March 30, 1934, Friday

Otto H. Kahn, philanthropist and patron of the arts, died shortly after 1:45 P.M. yesterday at the offices of Kuhn, Loeb Co., 52 William Street, the private banking firm in which he was senior partner. His death shocked his associates and members of the financial community by its suddenness.

On 5 September 1913, fire destroyed sixty blocks of Hot Springs, Arkansas.  It started in a laundry and was blown by winds into the fashionable residential area along Malvern Avenue.  A sanitarium, a high school, a stylish hotel, a courthouse, and a Methodist church were all destroyed in the blaze.   Amazingly, no lives were lost in the fire; but about 2500 people were left homeless.

From Wikipedia: 

William Jay Gaynor (1849 – September 10, 1913) was an American politician from New York City, associated with the Tammany Hall political machine. He served as mayor of the City of New York from 1910 to 1913, as well as stints as a New York Supreme Court Justice from 1893 to 1909.

Early in his term, Gaynor was shot in the throat by James J. Gallagher, a discharged city employee. Gaynor remains the only New York City mayor to suffer an assassination attempt. ... Although Gaynor quickly recovered, the bullet remained lodged in his throat for the next three years. During his term as mayor, Gaynor was widely considered a strong candidate for Governor or President. Tammany Hall refused to nominate him for reelection to a second term, but after accepting the nomination from an independent group of voters, he set sail for Europe. Six days later, on September 10, 1913, Gaynor died suddenly from the lingering effects of the shooting.

I'm still inclined to think the scale and decoration are that of a liner and not of an elegant steam yacht. The steps with a woman on in the background don't look like a yacht to me. The Corsair used for the trip up river would have been Corsair III, which became the USS Oceanographer after his death en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Oceanographer_%28AGS-3%29 She was over 300 ft long but only 33 ft wide. This side deck would have been a substantial percentage of that. I've just found www.navsource.org/archives/09/10/1003.htm with a 1916 picture of the Corsair (after requisition for WWI service). She has many more windows and no light paint on her superstructure. www.navsource.org/archives/09/10/09100304.jpg

Wystan, I do note the dates, but we both know that the dates can relate to date of use rather than date of capture. This just doesn't look as though it could be on the Corsair in the 1916 photo. So here's the result of a different line of investigation -- looking for pictures of the Lusitania that might have windows like these. See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2515735403/ If you look at the high-res TIFF and zoom in at the upper deck under the aft funnel, you will see windows with these same curved upper panes (highlighted by the snow).

By thunder, swanq, it looks like you've nailed it! The evidence here is most persuasive. You have convinced me that the Lusitania was the setting of Haldane's shipboard portraits. The New York Times story of August 30, 1913, explains that reporters (and presumably, photographers) came aboard the Lusitania on August 29, as it was detained briefly in quarantine [at Ellis Island(?)] before docking in New York Harbor. Viscount Haldane was affable, even humorous, as he allowed himself to be interviewed by the press. That would have been when the Bain cameraman had his chance to shoot the full-figure pose and the two closeups. New York Times story, August 30: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E05E4DC113CE6...
See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4058500130/ for very similar photo

There's no such title as "Sir McKenzie" (or "Sir Churchill") -- The title Sir is followed by the man's first name, as in "Sir Kenneth" or "Sir K. M." (or "Sir Winston.")

One should note also that this is not the original John Pierpont Morgan, fabulous financier, but his son, J. P. Morgan, Jr. (This photo was taken on August 30, 1913; the old J. P. Morgan died earlier in that year.)

There were a number of wrecks involving the Bar Harbor Express over the years, but this picture probably depicts the worst of them, which took place on the morning of September 2, 1913, north of New Haven, Connecticut. Travelling at 40 miles per hour in heavy fog, the White Mountain Express plowed through two cars of the Bar Harbor Express and overturned a third coach, killing 21 and injuring 50. Here is a page with links to a series of articles about the disaster, published between September 2 and September 5, 1913.

Grand Duke Alexander Mikhailovich of Russia (1866-1933) [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4256208753/] en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Duke_Alexander_Mikhailovich_o...

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4606573404/] In 1913, on his second visit to America (the first was in 1893), his Imperial Highness visited Philadelphia, Newport RI, and New York City. In New York, the Grand Duke stayed at the Ritz-Carlton hotel. One of several photos that Bain took there is dated September 6, 1913. After his departure for Russia, the New York Times (on October 5, 1913) ran a story about the unpretentious royal visitor, and included a story about a famous joke that Alex had played on the press in 1893: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9406EEDF1E3BE633A...

During his visit to Newport, Rhode Island in 1913, His Imperial Highness, The Grand Duke Alexander Mikhailovich of Russia (1866-1933), was struck by the beauty of American women. According to published reports, The Grand Duke "collected photographs of the women he met in Newport, especially at The Casino and Bailey's Beach." The Grand Duke was particularity smitten by Miss Marie Tailer of New York City, who was visiting Newport at that time, and he was "anxious to obtain a photograph of her". He declared that Miss Tailer was "The Most Beautiful Girl in the World". [1] This pronouncement was picked up by newspapers across the country (if not the world), and photos of Miss Tailer were published for some years afterwards -- always with the "Most Beautiful Girl in the World" moniker in the caption. [2] Marie Tailer was engaged in 1914, and married in 1915, to Mr. S. Bryce Wing. A photo of her is included in the LOC Bain Collection on Flickr -- however IMNHO there are more flattering photos of her in The (San Francisco) Call and The (Georgia) Evening Ledger.                         "Miss Marie Tailer (right) 1913"   from Bain / LOC

This young man is wearing rimless fingerpiece pince-nez eyeglasses which clipped on the bridge of the nose by spring powered nose guard grips. Properly fitted to the each individuals nose bridge, a pince-nez remained both secure and comfortable at all times despite the lack of temples or arms. It was by far the most stylish and popular eyewear of the period especially for young people. Attached to the right lens is a chain + earloop, a security device but just as many people wore a pince-nez without one because it always stayed perfectly in place.

Jacques Loeb was a German-born American physiologist and biologist. He was one of the most famous scientists in America, widely covered in newspapers and magazines and nominated many times for the Nobel Prize.

Joseph Chamberlain was an influential British businessman, politician, and statesman. Despite never becoming Prime Minister, he is regarded as one of the most important British politicians of the late 19th century and early 20th century, as well as a colourful character and renowned orator. He was Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's father.

Alberto Santos-Dumont was a Brazilian aviation pioneer, who designed, built, and flew the first practical dirigible balloons. He became the first person to demonstrate that routine, controlled flight was possible. Winning the Deutsch de la Meurthe prize on October 19, 1901, on a flight that rounded the Eiffel Tower, made him one of the most famous people in the world during the early 20th century.

Alberto Santos-Dumont,  a Brazilian who lived for many years in France, was an aviation pioneer who designed and built a number of successful aeroplanes in the infancy of powered flight. He is credited in 1906 with the first witnessed European takeoff, flight and landing of a heavier-than-air machine. He suffered later in his short life from MS, and died in Brazilat the relatively young age of 59.

I found the below photographs of Sinan's tomb in the Süleymaniye complex, Istanbul (ca. 1980) at the Archnet: Islamic Architecture Community digital library. The structures do not resemble the photochrom image: archnet.org/library/images/one-image.jsp?location_id=4395... archnet.org/library/images/one-image.jsp?location_id=4395... However, according to the book The age of Sinan: Architectural culture in the Ottoman Empire (Gülru Necipoğlu, 2005, p. 150), Sinan endowed a masjid (mosque) and school with a public fountain in Yenibahçe (now Fatih), Istanbul. The original masjid burned in 1918 and was restored in 1976. The photographs of the current building, show windows resembling the windows in the building in the above image, but differ in other ways: www.sinanasaygi.org/en/eserler.asp?action=eserDetay&I... It would be exciting if we could confirm that the photochrom image shows Sinan’s masjid before the fire of 1918. What do you think? Thanks for encouraging us to dig deeper!
